item.title: INTERVIEW WITH A BITCOIN EARLY ADOPTER
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1506452819137-0422416856b8?ixlib=rb-0.3.5&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&s=35c3a22e647b11004efd8135de82164c&auto=format&fit=crop&w=500&q=60 A lot of us can recall hearing about Bitcoin in the early days of its rise in public awareness. Like most things, it was a wave borne small and barely any different from the rest of the ripples on the surface of daily life. Very, very few of us saw it for what it was. And even fewer of those that did acted on it. It would have taken an amazing combination of conditions coming together to create the true Bitcoin early adopter. You would've had to have known at least a little about what were, at the time, somewhat divergent fields: cryptography, economics, software, e-commerce the list goes on. But Bitcoin is of course only one of many examples of people missing the boat on what would become life and sometimes world changing developments in technology. It takes a rare congruence of timing, skill set and position among other things for early adopters to, well, adopt. Henry Ford was ridiculed by colleagues for what they called his "contraption". Barely anyone could share his vision of a motorized "horseless carriage" carrying people to and fro across the land. Many of the prospective investors in the very early days of Amazon (who were approached by Jeff Bezos himself) simply couldn't believe in books being sold on "this thing called the internet". Even the computer itself was thought to be without a legitimate need for more than 5 or 6 pointsin the world. As ludicrous as it may seem, these sentiments were somewhat justified in their day and the arguments against them were few. People were all too accustomed to the status quo. They were busy with their lives. Focused on getting through the day. They'd "heard it before" and "knew better". They just weren't that interested. As with so many things that proved to be truly innovative, it was only the vision and fortitude of the individuals and teams behind the effort that brought these creations to fruition and rendered a huge service to humanity in doing so. If any of them had taken any of their critics even halfway seriously we'd likely be living in a very different world. In retrospect, it is strikingly clear (often frustratingly so) what the correct course of action would have been. If only I'd bought htis stock back then. If only I'd joined this team or known this person etc. Yes, life has a funny way of throwing things our way and leaving what happens to the smallest of details.The minutiae that determine what, ultimately, we act on and what we don't; and it all happens in the moment. Be that as it may, there will of course be further innovations and applications built upon them that will, in future years, take on the same authority and presence as the "digital giants" or our time do now. But who can say where they will start and how you, dear reader, will come in contact with them? https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1525248101004-b6859f6cfb61?ixlib=rb-0.3.5&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&s=e5c46bc2e07f2b59025cd20d657da74f&auto=format&fit=crop&w=500&q=60 It's all definitely food for thought. Anyway, to the point of this post: an interview with a real Bitcoin early adopter. We hope you will enjoy. 1.Please tell us a bit about your background. 2. How did you hear about Bitcoin? 3. What was your initial impression? 4. Can you talk a little about the community of people involved in the early days and the general feeling toward Bitcoin? 5. What made you decide to give mining (on a desktop!) a try? 6. Did you ever imagine Bitcoin reaching as high of a valuation as it has? 7. What do you think about the technology and philosophy behind Bitcoin? The technosophy if you will. 8. And, by default, what are your thoughts on the current frenzy defining a large part of the scene surround cryptocurrencies? 9. Why didn't you sell any of your Bitcoin yet? 10. How long do you plan to HODL? 11. No one can really say but, since you've been with Bitcoin since almost the very beginning, what do you imagine the future of Bitcoin to be?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Q&A with a man who was in the right place at the right time and had the right skillset when Bitcoin first arrived on the scene.

item.title: BLOCKCHAIN, AUTOMATION AND THE NEW ECONOMY
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
This post will admittedly be taking a slight departure from my usual focus on cryptocurrencies and blockchain. It will be focusing largely on the coming revolution of automation which the relentless improvements in both hardware and software over the past few decades seem to have finally prepared the world for. However, the subject is not completely unrelated to blockchain technology as there will likely be a need for it in tracking such a large volume of data being generated from so many different sources in a coherent and secure way. There will also likely be a greater need than ever before for this network to be transparent, accessible and decentralized. So please keep that thought in mind as you read the what follows.

REVOLUTIONS

A bird's eye view of the complete evolution of human technology and capacity would likely represent three distinct phases following the revolutions that spawned them. They would be in sequential order and with each leading to the other:
  1. The agricultural revolution
  2. The industrial revolution
  3. The informational revolution
It would probably be fair to add to this list the invention of the printing press. This single device is largely responsible for accelerating the dessemination of information among humanity to a degree and with a thoroughness that, without which, the onset of the industrial revolution could potentially have been delayed for some time. We should also bare in mind that, within each of these main revolutions, there are smaller sub-revolutions each introducting a further increase in efficiency and scalability. We could think of these smaller revolutions as iterations propogated by human minds each zeroing in progressively closer to an ultimate solution for the larger problem at hand. Further, in addressing the problem at hand, there has been a consistent trend, among all the revolutions, of a simultaneous increase in production and decrease in human labor. In changing from living as hunter-gatherers to farmers, human beings found themselves, probably for the first time, with free time to try and develop skills and endeavors related to areas with no connection to just finding enough food to survive. The industrial revolution leveraged this further by introducing a whole plethora of items and services that could be produced, transported and serviced on a scale and at a speed that was unprecedented. And finally, with the information revolution, we find ourselves with unlimited access to literally all information registered on the internet in the public domain. Slowly but surely our individual responsibility for our own survival has been augmented to the point where life has never been easier. However, with this gradual undercutting of the real world need for human labor we are inevitably reaching the point where there will be more people in need of work than there is work to give them. It would be safe to say that the dynamics of today's world are actually an inversion of those of our distant ancestors. Increasingly, the less skilled, powerful, wealthy and otherwise entitled among us find they are, in terms of accessible employment, becoming almost extraneous to the equation. As real as this crisis it it is not, by any means, a necessary one. At least if we are to look at the actual reality of the situation and not at the economic system through which it is managed. For that system is rapidly becoming an outdated one. And just as attempting to go through one's daily affairs on horseback would likely do more harm than good, so would continuing to rely exclusively on the economic system we have now for very much longer. But that is a point to be discussed later in this post. First, let us take a look at what is slowly coming to be acknowledged as the 4th revolution in humanity. THE 4TH REVOLUTION Today, in the early 21st century, many agree that a 4th revolution is coming. The revolution of automation or "The Automation Revolution". Automation has existed for some time, of course. Perhaps the most well known examples are the robots increasingly involved in large scale manufacturing. But automation goes far beyond robots repeating the same task endlessly. And the automation revolution will touch on far, far more industries than just manufacturing. While the work or pre-programmed robots in the factories of the world is impressive, they are not quite as capable as you might think. AsJim Lawton of Rethink Rebotics says, Traditional industrial automation requires hundreds of hours to reprogram, making it very impractical to change how the task is performed. So, while these robots may stand as somewhat traditional symbols of automation they are, in fact, suited only to a very limited niche- that of highly repetitive, non-changing tasks. True automation would require far more realy world functionality. Machines, computers and algorithms would actually need to be able to learn and, to a degree, think. Criteria like this call for artificial intelligence. Artificial intelligence has recently come under some scrutiny on the global scene. The potential for how powerful and potentially dangerous it could really be is only now beginning to be considered. While it is obvious that it would be more than capable of serving humanity to an incredible degree there are also those who feel it could quite literally end humanity on the spot. Such figures as Elon Musk are quite outspoken about the latter concern and his reasoning is quite logical. With previous revolutions in humanity, humans have always and necessarily been at the helm, so to speak, to control what is and isn't done with the new technological capacity. However, with A.I. there is real concern in regard to just how automated it should be allowed to be and what may happen, exactly, if someone "gives it the keys". One thing is for sure, the directives A.I. is given will be followed unquestioningly so we must be very, very careful about just what they are. However, a lot of this issues are, for the moment, purely philosophical. What is not philosophical is that A.I. is here and its widescale implementation seems all but inevitable.How this plays out will depend largely on how we as a species, our governments and our industries go about instituting it. Personally, while I feel that the concerns regarding A.I. are justified and should be addressed accordingly, I am optimistic as to the ultimate benefit humanity will receive through the large scale implementation of automation. Ultimately, in the long run it will likely be a very good thing; especially if we expect to survive into anything resembling the distant future. In the short term, however, it may prove to be a somewhat different story. WHERE AUTOMATION WILL AND WON'T HAPPEN WHERE IT WILL Be the dialogue concerning A.I./automation as it may, let's take a look at some of the concrete ways it will be implemented. As I said above, large scale automation extends far beyond the manufacturing industry. When we consider that automation will not appear in robots alone but in the algorithms and the computers and software that run them as well the potential areas and industries for it to be applied are almost unlimited. So, effectively, asking the question "Which industries will be affected the most by automation?" is equivalent to asking "Which industries will be affected the most be electricity?" or "Which industries will be affecte the most by the internet?" The answer isalmostall of them.And as this article from BBC.com makes clear, the effects will extend beyond the blue collar sector and well into the historically vulnerable middle-income, mid-skill job sector. Here is a list of jobs that, believe it or not, could be 100% replaced by automated technology: journalists, lawyers, drivers, chefs, financial analysts, telemarketers, customer service assistants, medics, construction workers and other manual labor jobs. Some of these jobs could be replaced sooner than others. Some of them may have another decade (at most) before they too are rendered obsolete. For a more detailed explanation of the details, click here to read the full article. It may seem obvious that high-skill, people oriented jobs such as those found in the medical, sales and entertainment industries would be difficult to replace with a machine. But it turns out that this, for the time being, is also true for extremely low-skill level jobs like washing dishes, picking fruit and any other kind of manual labor requiring dexterity in more than a very small number of different tasks. Machines can learn, see and, to a degree, think but they cannot manifest the requisite charm and human connection that a "people person" can. Nor can they be fully trusted to wash the dishes after dinner. Although we may likely see a hybrid of highly responsive robot technology either worn like a suit or guided like a remote control car in various industries such as construction, mining or even the military (where this is actually already happening). WHERE IT WON'T As aluded to above, machines and software can definitely replace tasks performed by people but they cannot, necessarily, replace people themselves. Most industries where clients expect to interact with an actual human being will likely remain relatively safe. This would include such industries as consultation, perosn-to-person sales, nursing, a good portion of education, entertainment and any other industry involving person-to-person care and interaction. However, these industries will likely be heavily augmented and supplemented by automation. It is interesting to note that, with the continuing rise of automation and computerization and its subsequent elimination of jobs in the once human dependent industries of manufacturing, data analysis, distribution and sorting etc. there has been a corresponding rise in the size of the service industry. This is a natural, evolutionary even, result of people naturally adapting to changes in the economic environment and finding work in fields where they are required. But, of course, the service industry, no matter how large, could not possible compensate to the degree it would need to in the face of the initial changes in the job market if and when large scale automation really begins to see implementation. HOW WE MAY BE AFFECTED IN THE SHORT TERM Two things are abundantly clear. 1) The rise of automation is almost inevitable simply because of the coercive force of competitive pressure. As adoption rates increase, companies will simply have to automate or fail. There will be no third option regarding this; regardless of one's political, social or academic beliefs the economy will bend to the invisible hand of the market. 2) Automation is on a collision course with the current economic structure. While mass fear of economic disruption via new technology extends at least as far back as the Luddite Riots of the 19th century, it is quite safe to say that full scale implementation of automation has the potential to create mass disruption on a scale that has never been seen in the history of the world. Automation stands literally to change the face of the world as we know it. With every turn of the wheel in the age of information, more and more jobs have been rendered obsolete and never to return. Automation could very well be the final blow to the current infrastructure. We will, in short, have become too efficient for our own good. The ancient progression of improvement which started with our prehistoric, hunter gatherer ancestors and has extended down through history to the present day will have effectively improved things so much that our need to work and therefore our jobs will be gone. Will we really have a world of utter segregation between the employed and unemployed? Will millions, no, billions of people really have to face a life of never being able to find a job? Some current analysts may actually believe this. Certainly, less informed segment so fthe population do. And, whether they know it or not, this rising tide of computerization and automation is the very source of a lot of the violent and extreme political movements around the world. There are, of course, other issues and too many to go into here but the issue of machines along with their algorithms somehow surpassing their creators in terms of employment is causing something of a paradigm shift to form. What is to be done? HOW AUTOMATION MAY STRUCTURE A NEW ECONOMY: UNIVERSAL INCOME? I said earlier that the looming crisis of automation need not be considered a crisis at all. Not if we are to re-examine our current economic structure and adapt it. And by adapt it I mean to focus it instead of on the traditonal and increasingly obsolete tenets of our post industrial past, to the actual needs of our time. And the needs of our time are very different from the needs of previous times. And they are becoming more so at an alarming rate. You see, in essence, there is no causal link between machines doing our work and human beings suffering for it. What there is instead is a strong perception of one and a pervasive economic platform that does not, as yet, have a means of adapting to a highly automated world. What I am saying is that, although there may be a time when most people will not have a job, in the conventional sense, this does not necessarily entail the downfall of civilization. This is a very important point to keep in mind. There is also another point to consider. If most people don't have a job, there will be very few people to buy the products and services automation is producing. So this leaves us in something of a quandry, a Catch 22 even. And it is obviously absurd. While in the beginning the paradigm shift may be a hard one (hopefully nottoohard) a time will inevitably come when a new level of stability and resulting prosperity is reached. But what will the solution actually look like? One proposed solution is Universal Basic Income (UBI) also known as Universal Income and/or Basic Income. To quote basicincome.org: "Abasic incomeis a periodic cash payment unconditionally delivered to all on an individual basis, without means-test or work requirement." What such a thing would do is provide an immediate level of functionality to every member of the society it was implemented in. As the productivity of society and the flow of its commerce from the point of natural resource extraction on through to retail sale and disposal and recycling would be largley in automated hands, there is no truly disputable reason for why such a program would be harmful to society in the least. HOW BLOCKCHAIN TECHNOLOGY MAY PLAY A PART

item.title: LIT SOCIAL MEDIA: A CRYPTO BASED VERSION OF INSTAGRAM?
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
Recent years have seen an unprecedented rise in the use of social media. First there was MySpace. Remember that? Then came Facebook. And the rest is history. With the rise of the smartphone and the many many ways to share our thoughts and lives online, the term "social media" has become almost as ubiquitous as "television". For better or for worse, social media is likely here to stay. And, as with all tools that empower change, it is important to make sure you use them instead of them using you. But the trials and tribulations of social media and its various points of controversy won't be discussed in depth here although I will say I personally believe social media offers far more positive potential than negative. Also, it is interesting to note the different phases in technological evolution and adaptation that have led to the curent state of our world. With the rise of the internet, the whole world was invited to come "online" and remove the barriers of distance and time to accessing information. Web applications have made this progressively easier with every passing year. Next came the introduction of social media; a means for pure social interaction disocciated, again, from time and place. The next stage was the smartphone which added a faster, more portable layer to the internet via its remarkable hardware configuration. And now, to add yet another real world interface between the digital and the analog, we are seeing the rise of cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology. And, interestingly enough, there are one or two platforms that are tying all of these together. And in this post, I'll be introducing one of them: a new platform called LIT.As the plethora of ICOs has continued to multiply and diversify there have also been a few which have turned to the world of social media (you can read my writeup on STEEMIT, a very diffirent platform with a similar blockchain foundation here). Personally, I consider this a brilliant move as it incentivizes engagement for all invovled. There is also the added advantage of the platform being decentralized and the tokens being tradeable on crypto exchanges. LIT just started in the second quarter of 2018 and is tied to the coin Mithril (MITH). As the title suggests, if I were to choose a single platform to which LIT is most similar, I would say Instagram. This is largely because LIT seems to focus exclusively on images and direct messaging. Their "stories" section is actually more of a photo gallery showing submissions from other users. The app is, as of yet, admittedly confusing although it does seem to have an enthusiastic core membership. It should be remembered that it is still in Beta and only a few months old so I'm sure the user experience will become clearer and more enjoyable as things evolve. The team behind it is dedicated and seem focused on transforming the platform into something great. You can learn more about them at their website here or you can visit them on Facebook. To give you some idea of what I'm talking about read the words of Mithril's founder,Jeffrey Huang, from his short paper "Let's Take Back The Social Network" quoted in full:
"While it is generally expected that professional content owners such as singers, songwriters, and other digital rights holders are able to monetize their content, content creators outside of this traditional model do not benefit from the economic value they generate in social networks. Increasingly, valuable content is generated from all walks of life, through video blogs, audio/podcasting, live-streams, and the like. We believe that everyone who adds value to the network should benefit from their work."
And further:
"To realize this future where all participants in the social media ecosystem can be rewarded for their contributions to their social network, we are very excited to launch the Mithril (MITH) token. Whether you are a popular celebrity, admired livestreamer, or everyday user, you can participate in network value that you help create through social mining on Mithril."
Most blockchain based social media platforms tend to focus on the principles of empowering individual users and kind of democratizing the platform to render it based on content and not on who has the biggest budget or the most market backing.
The coin the platform runs on, Mithril has faired rather well considering the current crypto market. Where many coins have lost over 60% of their value MITH seems to be holding at somewhere between 0.60 and 0.30 USD per token. Not too bad considering how fast and furiously some tokens fizzle when their ICO goes live. The fact that the platform is tied into the coin and vice versa means that MITH, unlike a huge number of other tokens out there, is actually tied into a real world plarfrom generating use cases. This is incredibly important if any long term, sustainable value is to be generated. But enough of all that, let's get into how the platform works and some thoughts on the potential it has.

Lit App: Earn Free Mithril (MITH) Social Mining

Mithril Decentralized Social Media Platform

bySagar Jaid
April 15, 2018
2
609
SHARES
2k
VIEWS
Share on FacebookShare on Twitter
Mithril is new a decentralized Social Media Platform based on the ERC-20 standard of the Ethereum Blockchain. Mithril (Lit app) another token like Steemit and Electroneum which are social media networks with a decentralized approach, where user or creator of content receives Rewards for contributions to the Blockchain Network.
Users can mine Mithril tokens through a concept called Social mining. Each users content and social interactions generated in the mithril ecosystem will mine MITH based on our algorithm. mith.io
Mithril and Ethereum Blockchain network allow recording, distribution and mining of Mithril.

What is Social Mining?

Social mining is a brand new concept that rewards all content creators. By simply sharing your stories on a platform, User can earn rewards based on your content, engagements and social influence. lit.Live

What is Lit app?

On 13 April 2018 Mithril Ltd Lunches Lit app onGoogle play storeand App store (Lit Mine your Mithril) beta version. Users can share their stories via lit stories, and be rewarded with Mithril tokens based on their stories impact and influence across the network. Download Lit beta version.

Lit app Has 6 main features in beta Version.

Lit stories

Lit stories are similar to stories on Instagram and Snapchat platforms, stories will last for 24 hours before disappearing. Stories can include posts, videos, slideshows, or individual photos. (some features are not yet available)

Lit Camera

Lit will also integrate with the camera on mobile devices and use advanced modern algorithms for cameras to deliver features so lit users can take excellent videos and photos with filters and some basic effects.

Lit Personal Chat

The lit personal chat allows users share stories between friends.

Lit Discover

Lit discover lets users find new people to follow and connect.

Lit Profile

The lit profile lets User manage their personal data and stories. users can grab your username and write Bio in the app, but you cant put a link in your Bio. users can also see your earned mithril.

Lit Notification

The lit notification help with notification and who are the people following you i.e you are a friend now. With the hype of more than 30 % in just one week. Founder Jeffrey Huang and an entire mithril are looking forward to making something great in social media via introducing blockchain social media by empowering content creators. AsMithril Ranks on 73 Ranks onCoinmarketcapon 15 April 2018.
Mithril (MITH) 1MITH = $0.665947 USD Market Cap $202,870,155 USD Whitepaper
Volume (24h) $125,095,000 USD Circulating Supply 304,634,084 MITH Total Supply 1,000,000,000 MITH

item.title: Reasons why Bitcoin could still be undervalued. NOT overvalued.
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
[et_pb_section fb_built="1" _builder_version="3.0.47"][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.47" background_size="initial" background_position="top_left" background_repeat="repeat"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.47" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"]

Don't have time to read the post? Watch or listen to the video commentary instead. Don't be shy about liking and subscribing at our YouTube channel.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_video src="https://youtu.be/pgR1sba5y6g?list=PLT1uEgaSpJGEHzXmuVFe4GYWwNCAuUTst" _builder_version="3.0.89"][/et_pb_video][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89" background_size="initial" background_position="top_left" background_repeat="repeat"]

 

At the end of my last post I briefly gave my reasons as to why I believe Bitcoin could be undervalued. Yes, undervalued. That is, even at what are considered by some to be crazy prices, Bitcoin could still be worth considerably more. Click here and scroll down to the last paragraph of the post if you'd like to see what I'm talking about. If not, read on. :-)

Before we can talk about why Bitcoin is potentially undervalued, though, we have to establish two points:

1. The meaning of value

2. What makes a currency, any currency, valuable.

POINT NUMBER 1: WHAT IS VALUE?

According to Merriam Webster's Dictionary the meaning of the word valuable is the following:

1a:having monetaryvalue
b:worth a good price

2a:having desirable or esteemed characteristics or qualities

  • valuablefriendships
  • of great use or service
  • valuableadvice

In the case of Bitcoin, and other cryptocurrencies like it, we can see that all four meanings of this definition are met. That's because Bitcoin actually does more than just represent a currency, it is the currency. This is a subtle but fundamental difference between some (but certainly not all) cryptocurrencies and our old friends like the US Dollar and Co.This is part of what is driving the cryptocurrency wave and I'll write about that further on in this post.

POINT NUMBER 2: WHAT MAKES A CURRENCY VALUABLE?

If someone were to ask you why gold is valuable or why the dollar or any other currency is valuable, could you answer? What would you say? Many of us would fall back on reasoning that probably boils down to something along the lines of "because it is". Others would point to graphs and enter a kind of disconnected fit of jabbering at you. And others might be able to explain what's actually happening in simple terms:

Here it is: there are three interdependent factors that generate "value" for a currency. Without all three, the currency is in serious trouble and it's only a matter of time before this becomes a problem. The three factorsare:

1. scarcity: a limited amount of the given currency. In the classic "supply and demand" equation, scarcity equals a limited supply. If an asset is either naturally or artificially scarce but useful it's value will be quite stable and will increase in relation to an increase in demand for it. Think cigarettes in prison or a supply of freshwater when lost at sea.

2. use: a history of use of a currency and facility in doing so. Use equals the "demand" aspect in supply and demand. If demand for a given currency increases but the supply doesn't the value will rise. However, if the supply also rises, value will either stay the same or decline i. e. inflation.

3. agreement/coercion to agree:a community which either agrees or is forced to agree on the validity of a given currency. This is probably the most subtle of the three aspects because most people are very much inclined to think only that "money is money" without really questioning why. The fact is that, without a community to support the circulation and use of a given currency, it would be effectively useless. This group attribution of value to currency has been an incredibly strong but entirely psychological factor in history. Generally, once agreement is established, it tends to persist more or less unquestioned. When agreement is challenged, the deeper currents of coercion involved in maintaining it tend to rise to the surface. This can range from talking heads on TV denouncing the challenge all the way to state sponsored violence on a national and/or international level.

Essentially, what all centralized kingdoms, governments, empires and countries have have historically done to ensure order and hierarchical control is to control what is and isn't a valid currency. At times when control has been threatened, simply changing the national currency has effectively stopped any challenge short. This notion of a nationalized currency is probably one of the most subtle and powerful techniques of injecting value into a currency because it is so widely accepted and unquestioned. At the same time it also either encourages or inhibits activity among a population to a remarkable degree because exchange of goods and commodities is controlled by the currency it happens in.

This is not to say that nationalized currency is inherently bad or that we are slaves to our economic overlords etc. Indeed, their is an element of stability and liquidity maintained in having an agreed upon currency controlled by a trusted 3rd party (the government). And most importantly, until very recently, there has literally been no better way. Despite the incredible advancements in technology over the past 100 years or so, our money system has changed very little since the days of Isaac Newton. This is definitely something to consider.

So, basically, without these three factors: 1) scarcity (actual or artificial) 2) use and 3) coercion/agreement a currency is effectively useless as a currency. Conversely, as long as these three conditions can be somehow maintained in the population/geographic locale using a given currency, that currency could literally beanything. Take the list below as an example:

  • Cows
  • Rice
  • Gold
  • Clam shells
  • Copper
  • Blankets
  • Salt
  • Decorated belts
  • Beads
  • Fish

Yes, these items have all been used at some point in history as actual currency. And only one of them maintains any kind of "value" today: gold. But good luck trying to buy anything with it.

Let me ask you this: what, besides agreement, makes gold valuable? What, besides agreement, makes money valuable? The answer is very little if anything. Not to undermine the validity of the current economic system or the efforts of both those who make it go round and those who get up every day to go to work for it. But, what if there were abetter way? Cryptocurrencies could very well be a better way. Theyare very likely here to stay and will most probably see prolonged, if volatile growth from here on out. In fact, with certain classes of cryptocurrency, they actually have the potential to accrue even more value than nationalized "FIAT" currency; particularly if they are decentralized.

UNDERVALUED? SERIOUSLY?

Yes, indeed. Talking heads on TV and the wizards offractional reserve bankingaside, Bitcoin could very well be undervalued. Here's why:

REASON NUMBER 1: the scarcity of Bitcoin is guaranteed. There are currently approximately 17,000,000 BTC in circulation and there will never be more than 21,000,000, Further, the rate at which they can be unlocked is fixed and we will not see the last Bitcoin mined until 2040. Any attempts to duplicate or counterfeit a Bitcoin will be immediately detected by the blockchain and will be impossible to verify. This is not so much a case of someone catching attempted fraud as it is the technology simply following protocol.

As an analogy, consider a total supply of 21,000,000 bars of gold. All of which will be released in precisely calculated intervals based on requisite levels of applied effort to unlock them (crypto mining) being met. The gold bars cannot be duplicated and their amount can never exceed 21,000,000. They also contain a unique code which links them to an overall whole. Any attempt to somehow make and introduce another bar of gold without A) the requisite amount of (verified) work being met and B) the coded inclusion into the whole will not be accepted. End of story.

This may be somewhat oversimplified but shows the essential foolproof elegance of the blockchain: if it's not a part of the blockchain, it's not a part of the blockchain.

This kind of scarcity is actually unprecedented in the history of currency. Some may say "what about gold?". Well, the truth is, there is more gold locked in the planet than we know what to do with. The only obstacle to getting it is the time, expense and, after a certain degree, technology it takes to get it. Gold can also be hoarded in secret, melted down, painted, hidden and otherwise kept from the knowledge of others. We actually may not know the total quantity of gold available on the markets to say nothing of how much more lies buried in the ground beneath our feet.

The exact opposite is true in the case of Bitcoin. Please consider what this may mean in regard to the scarcity factor so necessary to maintain and increase a currency's value.

REASON NUMBER 2:the second factor in determining a currency's value: use. There is a reciprocal relationship in the combination of a currency's scarcity and use i.e. supply and demand. That is, the more people use it, the more valuable it will become. With Bitcoin it is actually limited in supply not justeffectively limited (effective limitation being withholding large reserves or otherwise controlling the available supply in circulation).This reciprocity is fueled further not only because it is seeing accelerating use in spite of its limited supply but also because the technology itself offers multiple advantages over more traditional currencies such as:

  • transportability: Bitcoin, along with just about all other cryptocurrencies, has an unprecedented level of liquidity. It can be moved peer to peer (no bank or brokerage required) to anyone, anywhere, anytime on the planet in about 10 minutes
  • privacy: details of the transaction such as who is sending it, where they are sending it and why are exceedingly difficult to discern with cryptocurrencies. Unless you have a level of computing power comparable to the NSA, there is simply no way the average person could have any knowledge of the transaction.
  • security: the nature of the blockchain is security. This is one feature that is helping to drive the use and popularity of this technology. Bitcoin was the first platform to successfully implement and generate solid use cases.
  • convenience: again, peer to peer. That about says it all. All you need is an internet connection to have the same level of control over your funds and where they are going as any bank in the world.
  • historically unprecedented growth potential: current estimates say that less than 1% of the global population is involved with Bitcoin. Consider what this means in terms of potential for growth.
  • facility: this is a point that regular nationalized, fiat currency simply cannot compete with. Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies function as a platform whose nature is fundamentally different from the traditional world of money and banks. So different, in fact, that cryptocurrencies could almost be thought of as a kind of "money 2.0". This single point alone is enough, over time, to completely revolutionize finance as we know it.

REASON NUMBER 3: that oh so nebuluous element of coercion and/or agreement. But more so coercion. You see, Bitcoin isdecentralized. There is no one individual, one institution or one government that has ultimate control over Bitcoin. It is, by it's very nature, a distributed, communal technology. All Bitcoin transactions display equally on every computer on the planet. They cannot be altered, duplicated, deleted, bribed or otherwise subjected to any tomfoolery. This is absolutelynot the case with what we have been using as money for the past few centuries or, more recently, since the demise of the gold standard.

So what does this mean? It means that Bitcoin and, very importantly, other cryptocurrencies like it, represent an as yet unprecedented platform for transaction. Yes, there will be further developments and new types of technology. Yes, the capacity of Bitcoin will likely be surpassed in terms of transactions per second and the adaptability of the blockchain. But, remember element number 3? Agreement.

HOW HIGH COULD BITCOIN GO?

Currently, the only thing really holding Bitcoin back from stratospheric valuation is the size of its market and a relative lack of use in comparison to the size of the global population. It is currently estimated that less than 1% of the global population is involved with Bitcoin. As a comparison, the internet which may well be one of the greatest inventions of the 20th century currently sees use by approximately 40% of the global population. This is actually a pretty impressive figure considering that the internet is still relatively young. It is also, by it's nature a platform of nearly unlimited accessibility and expandability that is slowly but surely changing how human interaction happens across the planet.

Bitcoin, on the other hand, is not a a platform of unlimited accessiblity or expandability; although it does allow a high degree of divisibility (1 BTC can be divided into 100,000,000 units called a "Satoshi). Bitcoin is a platform that guarantees a rise in value the more it is used. With this in mind, imagine what would happen to the price of Bitcoin if it were to see use by even 10% of the population? To see where this is going we need to keep one thing in mind:

Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies in general are still in their infancy.

To continue the internet analogy, we could say that Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies are roughly where the internet was in the first days of America Online. There is A LOT of room for expansion. This is especially true when we consider that the nature of cryptocurrency technology allows it to extend to areas of the planet that are essentially cut off from global finance at the present time. That is, not only do cryptocurrencies inherently have more utility than their Fiat counterparts, they also offer more accessibility. This could drive their value even higher and even faster than we'd like to admit.

So, back to how high it could go. Personally, I believe that if present trends toward cryptocurrency persist even at 10% of their current fervor, it would be very realistic to expect to see Bitcoin at $500,000 USD within the next 10 to 15 years. And that is a conservative figure. There are some who would say $1,000,000 or more in far less time.

One thing is for sure, though. Bitcoin has not yet reached its full value. How far it will actually go up and where it will stabilize is really hard to say but it will be interesting to watch the ride.

ARGUMENTS AGAINST BITCOIN'S CONTINUED RISE IN VALUE

Ok. So what about the naysayers? Of course there must be some possibility of Bitcoin losing its value just as there is with any currency. But I believe the likelihood is probably less than with traditional currencies. That is, in a very real sense, Bitcoin is likely a more stable platform than something like the US Dollar or British Pound and other national currencies. This may no be immediately obvious. And some may call it a totally wrong opinion. So, for those who would disagree, let me explain the reasoning behind my opinion.

WHY BITCOIN'S DOMINANCE WILL BE DIFFICULT TO CHALLENGE

1. the total number of Bitcoin cannot be increased except through mining and the total number that will ever be available is absolutely fixed. This is not true with fiat currency or even with gold for that matter. With the US Dollar, the Federal Reserve can simply just print more money or the banks can use fractional reserve banking to literally create funds out of thin air; and then charge interest on it. This is what causes inflation and, eventually, terminal instability in an economy. It keeps everyone happy and things running smoothly for a time but the currency inevitably loses value to the point where it becomes useless (too much supply, not enough demand). And so "pop" goes the bubble etc.

Because the number of Bitcoin cannot be artificially increased it means it is actually quite difficult for inflation/devaluation to happen; probably even more so than gold. Actually, if anything,deflation is more likely. That is the value is far more likely to rise than to fall provided the three factors of use, scarcity and agreement on it as a medium of exchange persist.

2. Bitcoin is a far more secure platform. It essentially cannot be hacked or manipulated. However, it can be lost or stolen. And there is no way to replace it. This means that, even if the banks wanted to, they could never either A) control Bitcoin the way they do fiat currency or B) play the same kind of games they do with fiat currency. This means thateven the banks have to play by the rules.

3. the Bitcoin blockchain is distributed. This means that no one single entity, institution or government has control over Bitcoin. The nature of the network itself requires a large number of "nodes" that function in an interdependent way. Bitcoin has no centralization so there is no single point of failure and no single point of control. This is a simple but highly ingenious way to guarantee a transparent, almost egalitarian structure to the network. And, again, ensures that even the banks and financial institutions of the world involved with Bitcoin have to play by the rules.

4. essentially, the factors of scarcity, use, and agreement are just too strong with Bitcoin to see it simply go away as a platform of exchange. It is so well designed and increasingly so well built into the emerging new system of global finance that it simply wouldn't make sense to do away with it. It would require an ever increasing number of people and institutions to suddenly and simultaneously abandon the network for Bitcoin to crash. And it is difficult to think of any reason why this would happen.

WHAT COULD POTENTIALLY DEVALUE BITCOIN?

history is full of exceptions so let's talk about what could possibly carry the potential to devalue the economic tank that is Bitcoin. What could cause Bitcoin to lose value or "the Bubble" to pop?

SCENARIO 1:

Probably the most likely cause would be a superior and somehow more popular technology taking over. Ethereum has come close to this and has seen an amazing ascendancy since it was first introduced in late July of 2015. Ethereum does have its advantages over Bitcoin but is still no where near as valuable. And that is probably because it is newer than Bitcoin and has not received the same amount of investment and use i.e. there is not as much precedent of agreement upon its value. Some have compared Bitcoin to "the gold" of the cryptocurrency world and Ethereum to "the oil". And these comparisons are quite accurate and useful.

However, again, this would still require a unanimous kind of abandonment of Bitcoin by a lot of people invested in it. Given such factors as the cost of mining a Bitcoin and its growing precedence as an accepted and fungible means of exchange, the likelihood of this happening seems increasingly remote and, well, bizarre. It would literally be the same as everyone in the world involved with gold suddenly and simultaneously agreeing that it wasn't useful anymore. Yes, itcould happen but remains very unlikely.

People may make comparisons to other transitions in technology like the Blackberry to the Smartphone or the LP to the CD to the MP3 in regard to the potential threat of superior technologies to Bitcoin. However, these types of comparisons aren't really accurate because we are not talking about an improvement in a consumer technology. We are talking about an improvement in a system of money. And the parameters and requirements are quite different. Until the inception of Bitcoin, money had not fundamentally changed in centuries save for President Nixon taking the US Dollar off of the gold standard in 1973. The achievement of what money does is actually an extremely simple thing: complete a transaction of exchange where two parties can agree that the transaction has happened and are satisfied with its results. Nothing more, nothing less.

To be fair, however, there are many cryptocurrencies available even today which have undeniable advantages over Bitcoin. Faster transaction times, more transactions per second, "smart contract" options, blockchains that are open source and can be modified and improved upon. The list goes on. And we can only imagine what will come about in the years, decades and centuries to come in the way of innovations in this field. But still, Bitcoin dominates as the top cryptocurrency. Just as gold dominates as the top physical store of value. Why?" We may ask. I would say it is because ofagreement on the value of a Bitcoin. Nothing less and nothing more.

SCENARIO 2:

A second possibility would be the governments of the world imposing strict regulations on Bitcoin or even making it illegal. North Korea was successful in doing this by simply changing its national currency almost overnight and rendering the older version totally useless. This is something that can very easily happen to a centralized currency with one point of control. As James Madison once said:"History records that the money changers have used every form of abuse, intrigue, deceit, and violent means possible to maintain their control over governments by controlling money and it's issuance."

But, given the private peer-to-peer nature of Bitcoin, trying something like this would likely prove exceedingly difficult to effectively enforce. It would probably take a level of effort approaching that of the ludicrous expenditures of "The War On Drugs". And it would probably share a similar level of futility. To really put an end to Bitcoin, whoever trying to do it would literally need access to and control over every single computer on the planet. Not a very likely scenario.

So it would seem that there is no realistic challenge to Bitcoin's dominance as the most highly valued cryptocurrency. Save for possibly a change in trend more so than in a failure of Bitcoin as a platform for distributed, secure digital transaction.

Despite the many "netizens" opinion otherwise.

WHAT THE FUTURE OF BITCOIN WILL PROBABLY LOOK LIKE

Given that there are an increasing number of new cryptocurrencies coming out all the time it would be hard to say that the status and/or utility of Bitcoin will stay the same; most especially the utility. You see, honestly speaking, as a means of worldwide global transaction Bitcoin is just not up to the job. In the early days the case was very different but suffice to say the Bitcoin of today is nowhere near as convenient or cheap to work with as it once was.

And there are a huge number of technologies that can do what Bitcoin was intended to do better, faster and with more options.

However, good ol' BTC still holds immense value and has all of the signs to continue accruing more. So what will the future of Bitcoin look like?

Many seem to agree with the idea that Bitcoin will move increasingly away from use as an everyday currency and more toward use as a store of value. That is: aninvestment vehicle just like gold.The same reasons that make Bitcoin an arguably better form of currency than just about anything else we've come up with in the past 10,000 years also make it an amazing platform as a store of value.

So, the future of Bitcoin probably won't see many people using it to buy a cup of coffee or something off of Amazon. It will most likely be approached as something like gold is today:

highly valued: as outlined above there are far more reasons for Bitcoin to gain value and stay that way than there are for it to lose value. Gold has this quality, too. But it is actually somewhat artificially controlled. Given the nature of the Bitcoin technology, artificial control of it would be extremely difficult.

difficult to attain:as Bitcoin's value continues to increase while its availability decreases, it will invitably become ever more difficult to attain. Gold has seen waves of buying sprees and historical rises and falls in value but the truth is that, while it is admittedly difficult to attain, there is always more of if in the earth.

a wise investment regardless of the times:in times of political and economic strife many revert to gold because it has historically been the go to currency for store of value and longevity. Why this is so is somewhat difficult to understand unless we go with the explanation that everyone else thinks so, too. In the case of Bitcoin, provided no unprecedented bizarre event somehow wipes it off the planet in one fail swoop, it is likely to be seen as a go to store of value for far more logical reasons than gold: namely ease of transport, concealment and exchange.

If this does indeed become the case, it is likely the price of Bitcoin could see a valuation that would seem ludicrous today. Only time will tell.

At the end of my last post I briefly gave my reasons as to why I believe Bitcoin could be undervalued. Yes, undervalued. That is, even at what are considered by some to be crazy prices, Bitcoin could still be worth considerably more. Click here and scroll down to the last paragraph of the post if you'd like to see what I'm talking about. If not, read on. :-)

So let's talk about some historical and very logical reasons as to why Bitcoin may be undervalued.

First, we have to consider what factors make a currency, any currency, valuable. And before we talk about that, it would be good to have an objective definition of what the word "valuable" actually means. According to Merriam Webster's Dictionary the meaning of the word valuable is the following:

1a:having monetaryvalue
b:worth a good price

2a:having desirable or esteemed characteristics or qualities

  • valuablefriendships

b:of great use or service

  • valuableadvice

In the case of Bitcoin, and other cryptocurrencies like it, we can see that all four meanings of this definition are met. That's because Bitcoin actually does more than just represent a currency, it is the currency. This is a subtle but fundamental difference between some (but certainly not all) cryptocurrencies and our old friends like the US Dollar and Co.This is part of what is driving the cryptocurrency wave and I'll write about that further on in this post.

Now, as for what has historically made any currency valuable there are two factors that are widely accepted and discussed. And a third that, depending where in the world you live, could get you into real trouble by even mentioning it. The first two factors are scarcity and use. That is if something is both rare and useful it will inevitably be considered valuable. Another way to think of this is as supply and demand. Low supply (scarcity) and high demand (use), in the case of a currency, drive the price of that currency up. And this will be the case regardless of what people's personal opinion about the currency is; especially if they have no other choice to go with.

And this leads to the third factor: coercion. At the risk of sounding overly political and ingrateful toward my life in the first world, I should add that there are varying levels of coercion ranging from ultra-violence to the simple if effective psychological workings of marketing and other propoganda. Probably the most effective method is to simply remove all alternatives and give people only one way of doing things. And this is exactly what nationalized currency does; it coerces the population into using, norelyingon it. And this serves to generate value even if the actual deep structure of the economy using it is no more substantial than a monopoly game (see fractional reserve banking and you'll see I'm not joking at all). People may believe in the validity and substantiality of their own currency but, if you follow the trail long enough, you will find that it's not that substantial at all.

And this is historically what all kingdoms, governments, empires and countries have done: changed the money to serve their needs and limit the options of those below them. This is probably one of the most subtle and powerful techniques of injecting value into a currency because it is so widely accepted and unquestioned.

This is not to say that nationalized currency is inherently bad or that we are slaves to our economic overlords etc. It is simply an attempt to shed some light on the nature of money and how it either is or isn't used by a society. If the idea of coercion is too strong. Think instead of a highly encouraged level ofagreement as to the value of whatever is being used as currency in a given geographic locale.

Without these three factors: 1) scarcity (actual or artificial) 2) use and 3) coercion/agreement a currency is effectively useless. Consider this thought, as long as these three conditions can be somehow maintained in the population using a given currency, that currency could literally beanything. Take the list below as an example:

  • Cows
  • Rice
  • Gold
  • Clam shells
  • Copper
  • Blankets
  • Salt
  • Decorated belts
  • Beads
  • Fish

Yes, these items have all been used at some point in history as actual currency. And only one of them maintains any kind of "value" today: gold. But good luck trying to buy anything with it.

So what could possibly make Bitcoin, or any other cryptocurrency, impossible to have any value? The answer is nothing. In fact, with certain classes of cryptocurrency, they actually have the potential to acrue even more value than nationalized "FIAT" currency; particularly if they are decentralized.

So, back to Bitcoin. How could it be undervalued? What are the reasons?

First reason, the scarcity of Bitcoin is guaranteed. There are currenlty approximately 17,000,000 BTC in circulation and there will never be more than 21,000,000, Further, the rate at which they can be unlocked is fixed and we will not see the last Bitcoin mined until 2040. Any attempts to duplicate or counterfeit a Bitcoin will be immediately detected by the blockchain and will be impossible to verify. This is not so much a case of someone catching attempted fraud as it is the technology simply following protocol.

As an analogy, consider a total supply of 21,000,000 bars of gold. All of which will be released in precisely calculated intervals based on requisite levels of applied effort to unlock them (crypto mining) being met. The gold bars cannot be duplicated and their amount can never exceed 21,000,000. They also contain a unique code which links them to an overall whole. Any attempt to somehow make and introduce another bar of gold without A) the requisite amount of (verified) work being met and B) the coded inclusion into the whole will not be accepted. End of story.

This may be somewhat oversimplified but shows the essential foolproof elegance of the blockchain: if it's not a part of the blockchain, it's not a part of the blockchain.

This kind of scarcity is actually unprecedented in the history of currency. Some may say "what about gold?". Well, the truth is, there is more gold locked in the planet than we know what to do with. The only obstacle to getting it is the time, expense and, after a certain degree, technology it takes to get it. Gold can also be hoarded in secret, melted down, painted, hidden and otherwise kept from the knowledge of others. We actually may not know the total quantity of gold available on the markets to say nothing of how much more lies buried in the ground beneath our feet.

The exact opposite is true in the case of Bitcoin. Please consider what this may mean in regard to the scarcity factor so necessary to maintain and increase a currency's value.

The second reason Bitcoin may be undervalued concerns the second factor in determining a currency's value: use. There is a reciprocal relationship in the combination of a currency's scarcity and use i.e. supply and demand. That is, the more people use it, the more valuable it will become. And that is because it is actually limited in supply not justeffectively limited.This reciprocity is fueled further not only because it is seeing accelerating use in spite of its limited supply but also because the technology itself offers multiple advantages over more traditional currencies:

transportability: Bitcoin, along with just about all other cryptocurrencies, has an unprecedented level of liquidity. It can be moved peer to peer (no bank or brokerage required) to anyone, anywhere, anytime on the planet in about 10 minutes

privacy: details of the transaction such as who is sending it, where they are sending it and why are exceedingly difficult to discern with cryptocurrencies. Unless you have a level of computing power comparable to the NSA, there is simply no way the average person could have any knowledge of the transaction.

security: the nature of the blockchain is security. This is one feature that is helping to drive the use and popularity of this technology. Bitcoin was the first platform to successfully implement and generate solid use cases.

convenience: again, peer to peer. That about says it all. All you need is an internet connection to have the same level of control over your funds and where they are going as any bank in the world.

historically unprecedented growth potential: current estimates say that less than 1% of the global population is involved with Bitcoin. Consider what this means in terms of potential for growth.

facility: this is a point that regular nationalized, fiat currency simply cannot compete with. Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies function as a platform whose nature is fundamentally different from the traditional world of money and banks. So different, in fact, that cryptocurrencies could almost be thought of as a kind of "money 2.0". This single point alone is enough, over time, to completely revolutionize finance as we know it.

The third factor concerns that oh so nebuluous element of coercion and/or agreement. But more so coercion. You see, Bitcoin isdecentralized. There is no one individual, one institution or one government that has ultimate control over Bitcoin. It is, by it's very nature, a distributed, communal technology. All Bitcoin transactions display equally on every computer on the planet. They cannot be altered, duplicated, deleted, bribed or otherwise subjected to any tomfoolery. This is absolutelynot the case with what we have been using as money for the past few centuries or, more recently, since the demize of the gold standard.

So what does this mean? It means that Bitcoin and, very importantly, other cryptocurrencies like it, represent an as yet unprecedented platform for transaction. Yes, there will be further developments and new types of technology. Yes, the capacity of Bitcoin will likely be surpassed in terms of transactions per second and what can and cannot be uploaded and secured forever on the blockchain. But, remember element number 3? Agreement.

Let me ask you this: what, besides agreement, makes gold valuable? What, besides agreement, makes money valuable? The answer is very little if anything. Not to undermine the validity of the current economic system or the efforst of both those who make it go round and those who get up everyday to go to work for it. But, what if there were abetter way?

ARGUMENTS AGIANST THE CONTINUED DOMINANCE OF BITCOIN

There is some possibility of Bitcoin losing its value just as there is with any currency. But I believe the likelihood is probably less than with traditional currencies. That is, in a very real sense, Bitcoin is likely a more stable platform than something like the US Dollar or British Pound and other national currencies. This may no be immediately obvious. And some would call it a totally wrong opinion. So, for those who would disagree, let me explain the reasoning behind my opinion.

1. the total number of Bitcoin cannot be increased except through mining and the total number that will ever be available is absolutely fixed. This is not true with fiat currency. With the US Dollar, the Federal Reserve can simply just print more money or the banks can use fractional reserve banking to literally create funds out of thin air; and then charge interest on it. This is what causes inflation and, eventually, terminal instability in an economy. It keeps everyone happy and things running smoothly for a time but the currency inevitably loses value to the point where it becomes useless (too much supply, not enough demand).

Because the number of Bitcoin cannot be artificially increased it means it is actually quite difficult for inflation devaluation to happen; probably even more so than gold. Actually, if anything,deflation is more likely. That is the value is far more likely to rise than to fall provided the three factors of use, scarcity and agreement on it as a medium of exchange persist.

2. Bitcoin is a far more secure platform. It essentially cannot be hacked or manipulated. However, it can be lost or stolen. And there is no way to replace it. This means that, even if the banks wanted to, they could never either A) control Bitcoin the way they do fiat currency or B) play the same kind of games they do with fiat currency. This means thateven the banks have to play by the rules.

3. the Bitcoin blockchain is distributed. This means that no one single entity, institution or government has control over Bitcoin. The nature of the network itself requires a large number of "nodes" that function in an interdependent way. Bitcoin has no centralization so there is no single point of failure and no single point of control. This is a simple but highly ingenious way to guarentee a transparent, almost egalitarian structure to the network. And, again, ensures that even the banks and financial institutions of the world involved with Bitcoin have to play by the rules.

4. essentially, the factors of scarcity, use, and agreement are just too strong with Bitcoin to see it simply go away as a platform of exchange. It is so well designed and increasingly so well built into the emerging new system of global finance that it simply wouldn't make sense to do away with it. It would require an ever increasing number of people and institutions to suddenly and simultaneously abandon the network for Bitcoin to crash. And it is difficult to think of any reason why this would happen.

However, history is full of exceptions so let's talk about what could possibly carry the potential to devalue the economic tank that is Bitcoin. What could cause Bitcoin to lose value or "the Bubble" to pop?

Probably the most likely cause would be a superior and somehow more popular technology taking over. Ethereum has come close to this and has seen an amazing ascendancy since it was first introduced in late July of 2015. Ethereum does have its advantages over Bitcoin but is still no where near as valuable. And that is probably because it is newer than Bitcoin and has not received the same amount of investment and use. Some have compared Bitcoin to "the gold" of the cryptocurrency world and Ethereum to "the oil". And these comparisons are quite accurate and useful.

However, again, this would still require a unanamous kind of abandonment of Bitcoin by a lot of people invested in it. Given such factors as the cost of mining a Bitcoin and its growing precedence as an accepted and fungible means of exchange, the likelihood of this happening seems increasingly remote and, well, bizarre.

People may make comparisons to other transitions in technology like the Blackberry to the Smartphone or the LP to the CD to the MP3. However, these types of comparisons aren't really accurate because we are not talking about an improvement in a consumer technology. We are talking about an improvement in a system of money. And the parameters and requirements are quite different. Until the inception of Bitcoin, money had not fundamentally changed in centuries save for President Nixon taking the US Dollar off of the gold standard in 1973.

To be fair, however, there are many cryptocurrencies available even today which have undeniable advantages over Bitcoin. Faster transaction times, more transactions per second, "smart contract" options, blockchains that are open source and can be modified and improved upon. The list goes on. And we can only imagine what will come about in the years, decades and centuries to come in the way of innovations in this field. But still, Bitcoin dominates as the top cryptocurrency. Just as gold dominates as the top physical store of value. Why? We may ask. I would say it is because ofagreement on the value of a Bitcoin. Nothing less and nothing more.

A second possibility would be the governments of the world imposing strict regulations on Bitcoin or even making it illegal. North Korea was successful in doing this by simply chaning its national currency almost overnight and rendering the older version totally useless. This is something that can very easily happen to a centralized currency with one point of control. As James Madison once said:"History records that the money changers have used every form of abuse, intrigue, deceit, and violent means possible to maintain their control over governments by controlling money and it's issuance."

But, given the private peer-to-peer nature of Bitcoin, trying something like this would likely prove exceedingly difficult to effectively enforce. It would probably take a level of effort approaching that of the ludicruous expenditures of "The War On Drugs". And it would probably share a similar level of futility. To really put an end to Bitcoin, whoever trying to do it would literally need access to and control over every single computer on the planet. Not a very likely scenario.

So it would seem that there is no realistic challenge to Bitcoin's dominance as the most highly valued cryptocurrency.

WHY IS BITCOIN SO VOLATILE?

This is a good question to ask and really has nothing to do with Bitcoin being "a bubble" or a "scam". Unfortunately, utter lack of understanding about something doesn't stop people from saying what they think on the news or internet. Anyone who would give even 15 minutes of time to sincerely study what Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies are about would probably come to the conclusion that they offer a lot of potential. The only exception would be if they are either to lazy or to stupid to stupid to understand it.

Bitcoin is volatile for one reason and one reason only: it is still a very small market. A good analogy would be Bitcoin is a rowboat. The US Dollar is an aircraft carrier. A small change can have a huge effect in the Bitcoin market where it would probably go unnoticed in the US economy.

WHAT THE FUTURE OF BITCOIN WILL PROBABLY LOOK LIKE

probably an addition to traditional stores of value and not altogether a replacement

a digital goldof increasing rarity

FINAL THOUGHTS

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MnY_vl7Ids8
