item.title: DISRUPTION: BLOCKCHAIN VS. THE STATUS QUO
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
[et_pb_section fb_built="1" _builder_version="3.0.47"][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"] CURRENT STATE OF AFFAIRS With the continuing rise of blockchain technology and its growing recognition as a new and better way of doing things, there is also a degree of FUD (fear and doubt) in regard to both the legitimacy of this type of technology and the potential level of disruption it may cause to the status quo. We seem to be at something of a crossroads here in the first half of 2018. We have, on one side, certain large institutions (the gatekeepers, if you will) whose very existence embodies the "trusted 3rd party" whom Satoshi Nakamoto proved utterly unnecessary (gulp) with the introduction of the Bitcoin Blockchain in January of 2009. On the other side we have an increasing number of individuals, startups and smaller institutions embracing this new blockchain technology and thinking of ever more services and industries it could facilitate along with ways to improve the platform itself. Indeed,things are happening with blockchain. The notion of becoming obsolete by simply being blown out of the water by something better is not a comfortable one. Nor is it a new one. The blockchain is to the current state of data management what the steam engine was to the industrial revolution. Evolution biological, technological or otherwise is not always convenient in how it manifests but it usually does, after a sometimes messy changeover, bring something better than what was before. TECHNOLOGY CARES NOT AND THE GOOD USUALLY WINS The fact of one technology superceeding and leaving another to the annals of history is nothing new. Nearly every modern contrivance in our daily lives is a newer, improved version of something older and now out of use. And going back even further, even older technologies were, in their day, improvements on something that came before them. The progression and evolution of technological capacity is a ruthless one. It is also highly democratic in that if a new technology offers a way of doing something more efficiently it will be adopted quite naturally among those who seek to use it. "The will of the people", so to speak, is quite strong in determine the trends of what is and is not accepted for mass adoption. There are exceptions, of course. Despite the rise of the computer, tablet and smartphones we still use pen and paper; although you'd be hard pressed to find a vendor to supply you with papyrus. Horseback riding, in spite of the numerous motorized ways of getting around, is still a popular hobby although your sanity would seriously be questioned if you rode a horse everywhere you went. And even in our world with its vast array of digital media in the form of videos, music and so on people still take the time to go to concerts and live performances of every kind, Even Shakespeare consistently packs the house after nearly 500 years of producing no new material whatsoever. Throughout history there has continuously been a cyclical kind of evolution to the development of technology and it is only growing more rapid and pronounced here in the 21st century. And it is doing so at a rate that is accelerating. So, it is safe to say that the world of today will soon be the world of yesterday. And the world of tomorrow will likely bare little resemblance to the world of today. Change is certain and, in our world of increasing interconnectedness, scalability, speed and sheer volume it is difficult to imagine what form these changes will take. And, further, how they will be handled. THE EXTREMES OF CHANGE AND ADOPTION The dynamics of the situation can be polarized as such: disruption and incorporation. Disruption being the initial shock to the area a new technology takes hold in and incorporation the gradual streamlining of this new thing into an eventual state of normalcy. And we are surrounded with case histories of these events. Historically, with the introduction of the majority of new technologies there has been quite a bit of exaggeration as to what the real impact will be. And by "exaggeration" I mean either vastly underestimating on one side or vastly overestimating on the other what the actual effects will be. With the introduction of the TV to nearly every household in the US, for instance, it was thought that the end of radio was near. With the introduction of digital media, many thought books made of paper would disappear from the earth. But, obviously, although these technologies did see widespread adoption, their predecessors continue to exist. So, although the initial disruption may send shock through its area of implementation the general level of speculation is rarely as accurate as we would like to believe. However, there are exceptions where a new technology is so undeniably good and does so much more so much more efficiently than whatever it is replacing that instead of incorporation, we see it totally supplanting its predecessor. Take firearms over the sword and spear. Automobiles and trains over horses. The computer over the typewriter, The internet over the telegraph (and just about everything else not totally dependent on a physical form to function). In each of these cases where adoption of one technology over another led to the essential demise of the former we can see the death of one industry and the birth of another. But this is another subject altogether and, if you are interested in exploring it, we recommend this article. Although it focuses on the more recent rise of robots replacing workers, the essential principle of technological evolution changing how things are done is the same. IS BLOCKCHAIN A GAME CHANGER? Is blockchain one of these exceptional technologies bound to blow everything else out of the water? Is it going to tank the current global system of digital transaction as we know it? Yes and no. Yes, because it is a game changer in the sense of the back end of all digital transactions becoming far more transparent, secure and distributed. But no in the sense of creating a revolution like we have seen with other technologies such as the automobile, airplane, personal computer etc. For those in the first world, instead of suddenly having a completely new ability made available to us, we will likely see a higher level of access and speed combined with a lower level of risk and associated fees/profit taking. However, for those in the third world, blockchain technology could very well be a massive game changer. But that is the subject for another post. I think it is likely we will see the blockchain functioning as an extension or substratum of our current system allowing it to work more efficiently. This is largely because instead of a fundamentally new technology like the airplane or the television, the blockchain is simply a software protocol; a new and revolutionary way of doing thingsin the digital world not the analog world As I said nearthe end of my last post,I believe widespread implementation of blockchain technology will not be that noticeable in the end-user experience. Aside from faster and easier transactions, potentially lower fees (assuming companies act fairly and pass their savings on to their clients), and a decrease in the amount of paperwork and procedure on the front end, implementation of blockchain technology may not be that noticeable at all, actually. For all the hype and marketing we hear regarding blockchain, it's actual real world application happens largely on the backend. There may be exceptions to this, of course, as future developments are implemented and the technology becomes more tested and proven over time. We may see, for example, a much larger degree of individual control in personal health care, real estate transactions, personal finance and even how our own personal information is handled by the businesses and organizations we interact with. THE SHORT TERM: WHAT MAY BE THE IMMEDIATE EFFECTS OF BLOCKCHAIN IMPLEMENTATION? The truth is, though, that for the time being there are simply too many factors involved and too many established institutions in the way to make any clear statements about the real future of blockchain one way or the other. However, I think the immediate applications and adoption of this technology will be relatively slow in coming. This is mainly because large companies, particularly those involved in core services such as finance, energy, governance and so on are rather like freight trains on cruise control. That is they do not lend themselves very easily to large scale change and tend to have a certain level of resistance to it. Inertia, tradition, beauracracy and, sometimes, full blown incompetence often conspire all too successfully to keep the status quo a littletoo status quo. In the case of blockchain technology we are not talking about a supplemental type of application or a system that will act as an extension of what is already in place. We are talking instead of a replacement for how data management is done. This is something that may well present potential clients and their companies with certain hesitations and concerns. This will, of course, be a highly temporary situation but is something worth considering: there is between the hype, capital and marketing being poored into blockchain development a gap separating it from the real world. And here are a few reasons why: it requires a degree of specialized knowledge: let's face it, as promising as blockchain technology is it still requires a considerable degree of computer literacy and coding ability to make use of in any direct way. It will therefore, as a service, likely remain in the hands of the developers and engineers actually building it. It would be hard to imagine the average Joe intereacting with blockchain technology without, at the very least, a more user friendly platform being designed, built and implemented by (wait for it) a third party. This intereface would be similar to something like an email account. Users would have secured private access to their own account and transactions but the actual traffic and work on the blockchain may or may not be accessible to them in a direct way. However, a record of it would most certainly need to be made accessible or the purpose of using blockchain in the first place would be altogether defeated. coordination with existing industries: to be even remotely useful, blockchain technology will need full acceptance from and coordination with the industries and communities using it. Although it is designed to function as a kind of stand alone, distributed platform users on both ends will need, at the very least, a degree of consensus and collective motivation in using it. They would have to agree that it's the way to go and need considerable reason to drop the current way of doing things before adopting a new one. Of course, if the first few use cases of mass scale blockchain usage are as successful as many hope, the proliferation of this technology throughout the digital world could likely see an accelerated rate of adoption. This was largely the case with the internet within a few years of its introduction and this proliferation has continued right up until today. smooth onboarding:this point is somewhat in line with the issue of mutual coordination between existing industries but deserves separate attention because it calls for something more fundamental: the full replacement, even if in stages, of current data management structures with something entirely new. This notion of "onboarding" i.e. bringing a new technology onboard and infusing it into the existing platform is not always as easy as it may sound. Of course this is not to say that blockchain technology is not up to the task. That would be a ridiculouls thing to say or even think. BUT, it is true that there is no single platform or use case with blockchain technology that approaches say, for example, the volume of digital transactions of a company like Google or Microsoft. THE MID TERM: WHAT THE EFFECTS OF LARGE SCALE IMPLEMENTATION OF BLOCKCHAIN TECHNOLOGY MAY BE Again, this is an area for which there simply isn't enough data available to make any accurate assumptions with any huge amount of certainty so please do take the following as you will. That said, I think it is likely that, after a few years of successful blockchain implementation and the use case data resulting from it, we will see an accelerated rate of adoption across the world. This will likely lead to widespread *"leapfrogging" in currently less developed areas of the world and to higher and faster rates of adoption among first world nations. With the massive labor and cost saving potential of blockchain technology, it is very likely that, with sufficient use case evidence of the real utility of this technology, we may see its adoption spread like wildfire exactly as the internet has and continues to do today. As it is now, there simply is not enough data to encourage overnight adoption of blockchain technology but there are many companies, IBM included, who are investing serious amounts of resources into studying and developing blockchain applications. It is likely that, once the competitive edge is made clear, something like a paradigm shift may occur (as is often the case when a new technology proves to be truly revolutionary) and any platformnot using blockchain will be made to look very silly indeed. So silly, in fact, that they may see themselves going bankrupt. *leapfrogging is the term given to the practice of jumping from either no technology or an outdated technology to one several stages of evolution beyond it. A now classic example is certain countries in the world going straight to cellular networks without ever having had the more traditional infrastructure for land line telephone technology. THE LONG TERM: WHAT MAY BE THE ULTIMATE EXTENT OF DISRUPTION OF THE STATUS QUO AND ITS RESULTING NEW FACE VIA FULL SCALE, ESTABLISHED BLOCKCHAIN ADOPTION? This is really the big question. Use, facility and issues concerning adoption aside, how will things have changed once blockchain technology has essentially replaced the current status quo of digital data management? To answer this, I think it is useful analyze how the world and nearly every element of our lives has been changed by the rise of the internet. For those of us who were around in the pre-internet days, we may remember it as a time of comparative inconvenience. Transactions essentially all happened in person, over the phone, via the occasional fax or even by what has now come to be known as "snail mail". Compared to today's online world of ever connected, ultra efficient light-speed communication and data/media transfer it is hard to imagine how anything ever got done before the internet. It may sound a silly thing to say but it really isn't that much of an exaggeration to say that what may have taken months in the days before the internet can now be done in a few days, hours or, in some cases, minutes. So, with full scale blockchain implementation I think we will see yet another increase in the magnitude of efficiency of daily data transactions in the same way we saw with the internet. That is, the level of independence, access and capacity we currently enjoy via online connectivity will see even more enhancement. We will get even more independent, have even more access and even more capacity. And it will be more secure. But then there is the issue of how current industries, those whose very existence is defined as being that old and ever-present "trusted 3rd party", will fare. For sure things on this front will change. In my last post I discussed 10 industries that could benefit from blockchain technology. They were: IOT network management, healthcare, supply chain management, retail points systems, the energy sector, the data marketplace, ID technology, copyright and royalty transparency, education and real estate. Now it stands to reason, by the very nature of blockchain, that those industries that could benefit from it will also, initially, see some disruption as well. Some may see themselves become a shadow of what they once were (think AT&T) others may see themselves leveraged by several orders of magnitude (think direct mail vs email marketing). A lot will depend on how the affected industries succeed or fail in adapting. History has shown that innovation rarely occurs more than but once in a single company. Oftentimes, the new growth curve will stem from an idea born in a different industry or by a different group altogether. It is the rare individual or company that can adapt to changes in technology gracefully enough to keep their operation unaffected or, at the very least, afloat. Assuming blockchain is fully adopted by those industries that stand to benefit from it most (or suffer the greatest losses for not adopting it) I think we will see a radical restructuring of how services are delivered and also in the amount of resources required to deliver them. This last point, a reduction in the amount of resources to deliver a service is quite profound when considering how much more current resources can be leveraged and the sheer number of people that stand to benefit from it particularly in currently developing regions of the globe. Some argue that we may see some institutions disappear altogether. To me this seems a bit of a stretch. While we will certainly see a reduction in the size and likely the power of many institutions as 3rd party overseers, their total disappearance may be pushing it. We will still need a means of interfacing with the blockchain in a way that is convenient and, further, coherent. This may come in the form of dedicated apps or other digital media but even these will still require a human presence to design, update and adapt them to the needs of the market. So, instead of seeing companies acting as the ultimate arbeiters of the services they currently offer, we may see them become something like portals to the blockchain in a similar way to search engines acting as portals to the internet today. Of course those companies that act as first movers in designing and structuring these kinds of services will naturally shoot to the forefront of a new frontier. Considering this, we can see how striking the analogies between the rise of blockchain technology and the internet the preceded it really are. In the same way that someone in the early 90's couldn't possibly imagine being able to visually check their bank balance, book a hotel, and chat with a friend on the other side of the world all from a device they can hold in their hand nor can we really imagine the level of convenience, independence and automation a truly integrated, accepted blockchain platform(s) could bring to the world. It is an exciting time and definitely one to stay up to date on.With new changes and developments happening all the time and new companies and applications coming together the future for blockchain looks very bright, indeed. PREVIEW Our next post will be focusing on how blockchain technology could potentially help a vast amount of humanity in the undeveloped world join the rising tide of globalization. PSST. Are you interested in getting involved in cryptocurrencies? If you want to learn about the service provders we work with, Mintage Mining and Crypto World Evolution click through to read about them. Or you can alwayssend us an email at: admin@bitcoinbuildify.com Be sure to include:
  • your first name
  • what service you are interested in
  • how best to correspond with you.
We prefer Zoom or Skype as this is the fastest and most direct way to show you how the tech works and to take care of any questions you may have. But were ok with email, too. We have a little more of an old school approach to servicing our clients:
  • no automated emails,
  • no affiliate link buttons
  • no hiding who we are
We believe in quality over quantity and want our customers to have a full understanding and appreciation of what theyre getting into. This helps us just as much as it helps you. :-) Once you send us an email, a real human will get in touch with you within 48 hours at the most. None of the information you share with us will be made available to any 3rd parties without first getting your interest and permission to do so. We hate spam just as much as you do. If you are a spammer, you will be put directly straight onto our naughty list Have a nice day.     [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]

item.title: CRYPTOCURRENCIES & BLOCKCHAIN: IMPLICATIONS BEYOND MARKET SPECULATION
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
[et_pb_section fb_built="1" _builder_version="3.0.47"][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89" background_size="initial" background_position="top_left" background_repeat="repeat"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.47" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.47" background_size="initial" background_position="top_left" background_repeat="repeat"]
 
[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"] IMPLICATIONS BEYOND THE ECONOMIC Cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology offer far more than just opportunity for market trading. They reduce the cost and expenditure of resources in digital transactions of every kind thus making more technology and opportunity accessible to more people. The platform is a revolution in how data management is done. This is naturally true for the currently developed world as such but also carries with it the special characteristic of being almost immediately applicable to the undeveloped world at no extra cost. And that is the subject of this post.   Cryptocurrencies and, more specifically, blockchain technology are not just about the money. Yes, there is a growing and potentially very profitable world of investment and trading opportunity out there and this is largely what has brought awareness of this new technology to public knowledge in the first place. But there lies, in the nature of the technology, a different kind of potential. We are talking about both an alternative to the current structure of the financial system and to how information is shared in general. This second point, how information is shared is extremely important. And by "sharing of information" I mean any type of digital transaction with any type of media: audio, video, text, bank transfers, insurance policies, medical records, real estate transactions and so on. It is a field of potential that extends well beyond the realm of finance and encompasses a level of applicabilitycomparable to the internet. Blockchain technology represents a generational opportunity to mutualize database infrastructure across entities within financial services. What that translates into is an enormous cost-saving, risk-reducing, and capital-enhancing opportunity. -Blythe Masters You see, with blockchain technology, the level of privacy and security afforded to anything on the registry is universal and so it's potential for application in nearly every aspect of digital life is effectively unlimited. Blockchain could be used just as easily for something like a social media platform as it could for an international banking system. Further, it is remarkably cost effective meaning a large amount of the resources and associated cost involved in digital data and transaction management is rendered unnecessary. This isblockchain effectively removes power from any overseeing third party and places it firmly in the hands of the end users. Further, through the use of smart contracts transactions of incredible complexity, far more complex than the simple financial ledger type transactions of the Bitcoin blockchain, can also be executed with the same characteristic privacy, security, and incorruptability that has made the blockchain so well known. Before going on, let me restate the following key points in order to make it exceedingly clear how, exactly, the implementation of blockchain technology could serve a nearly unprecedented increase in the level of access to and security of digital data and transactionability of nearly every kind simultaneously:
  1. Blockchain technology,when using a distributed model, eliminates the need for a 3rd party to manage and oversee transactions
  2. Because of this the associated costs, protectionism and high potential for usery among other things is "given no quarter" and effectively no chance to get started i.e. blockchain is cheap.
HOW THINGS HAVE BEEN For the majority of modern history the general trend in adminstration of transactions of nearly every kind has been one of specialization of human skill. What I mean is that the more complex the nature of the transaction, generally speaking, the more specialized and often expensive will be the provider of the service. Such occupations as doctors, lawyers, and engineers to name a few should serve as cases in point. There are facets of this type of system which for the time being are unavoidable. And so the expense of hiring a lawyer or staying in the hospital is, to a degree, justified. We would never ask just anyone to defend us in court or to treat a sick child. There is, then, a certain threshhold we must meet in requesting a service from a third party and this very often comes with a price. Sometimes a very high one. Until very recently this has really been the only choice. Life is short and resources limited. It has therefore been understandable that, in employing the services of another person with a specialized skill the price of the transaction has necessarily had to include a (financial) allowance for that person's livelihood. And this practice of adding fees to essential if basic services in order to support the welfare of the human beings providing it has continued right up to the present day. As the saying goes, "we've all gotta eat". However, with the proliferation of digital technology and the high level of automation and convenience it brings, the creative/productive capacity of a single human being has been leveraged to a degree that would have been beyond imagination not even a generation ago. For a very large number of the services and transactions of daily life, gone are the days of the need for ultra-specialization and the intense amount of resources once necessary to support it. The introduction of software, automation and, more recently, artificial intelligence have created a new dynamic in the world. One in which far more can be done with less. However, room for improvement still remains. Artificial intelligence and large scale automation are still in their infancy although they will likely generate profound changes in the years to come. In the meantime, there is a far more accessible and more easily implemented platform to help further the transition from ultra-specialization and reliance on 3rd parties: the blockchain. WHY WOULD BLOCKCHAIN MAKE A DIFFERENCE TO THE STATUS QUO? Basically, it comes down to this: the current system is highly inefficient, susceptible to corruption, too expensive and basically outdated. You could say that there are too many cooks in the kitchen, too many cooks taking a bite of the pie, and too many going without food. The cooks being the financial and governmental institutions of the world and those going without food being the marginilized and mostly ignored citizens of the developing world. Blockchain technology (of the decentralized variety) would effectively remove a large number of cooks from the kitchen. Gone would be the resource and funds consuming dominance of the plethora of trusted 3rd parties so commonly accepted in today's world. On the one hand this does prove an arguable threat to the many jobs and industries that would find themselves rendered obsolete. On the other hand, the far lower amount of resources required to manage a blockchain platform would mean easier access for more citizens of the globe. Particularly those in the less developed regions of the world. Aside from the massive problem concerning the distribution of wealth around the globe there is a second issue of how this wealth can be accurately and securely moved (see our article, What Is Cryptocurrency, for a better understanding of this point). The costs and infrastructure that have traditionally been used to support the financial system, aside from possessing the indelible flaws of a fiat monetary system, are also quite expensive; in fact they are cost prohibitive for a very large segemnt of the world's population. Again, however, when we speak of distribution of wealth via cryptocurrency platforms we may speak in equal terms (and without modifiying the essential technology) of distribution of any kind of information at all. This is because blockchain technology is not limited to finance alone but is capable of securing and representing any possible digital transaction of any digital media whatsoever at all.The coins and tokens involved with blockchain technology are, more often than not, there to provide incentive for use and to generate funding and interest for the underlying technology. INEFFICIENCIES? To be fair, the inefficiencies of the current system may not be all that obvious to those of us living in the first world. They may be seen largely as part and parcel of the system as it is or even as improvements over how things were done in more historic times; sometimes vastly so. However, history has clearly shown that what may be today's paradigm shift over yesterday's soon becomes yet another relic among the many stepping stones of humanity's technological evolution toward tomorrow. So we must keep in mind that further innovation is always possible. Hence the promise of the blockchain. STATE OF THE UNION So let us first admit that we are currently inhabiting a system that is in need of improvement. A system for which the tremendous expense and waste involved in supporting what has become a normal lifestyle in the first world goes almost completely unnoticed. Not so much because we don't care but because we either don't know about it or don't notice it. Such is the nature of accustomization. Nevertheless, it is there. Our energy grid, roads, water and sewer system, public education, military, and government are all tremendously expensive to build and maintain. They are also constantly under the threat of falling apart. There is, on top of this platform of civilization, a second element: that vast contraption spanning the gulf from the extraction of raw natural resources all the way to final retail sale known as the supply chain. All of this serves as the foundation for a normal life in the first world. So normal, in fact, that it has become all but invisible to the average person. The first world, however, still represents only a small percentage of the global population and its standard of living remains, for the most part, utterly out of reach for a surprisingly large portion of humanity. This is not to say that more people should participate in the expenditure of resources that currently constitute a "normal first world life", but that there is a better, more efficient way. A way this is also a more transparent and secure method of delivering a comparable standard of living to a far greater number of people at a far more economic rate of consumption of resources. The trick is not to load more onto the current platform but to replace it with a newer, higher performance platform that can do more with the same or even a lesser amount of resources. THOSE THAT SUFFER For those born and raised in the first world it is somewhat difficult, to say the least, of what constitutes daily life for those inhabiting the less developed regions of the globe. Although there has been no shortage of philanthropic efforts of every kind to change things, there remains a huge number of human beings for whom which there has been little or no change at all in their standard of living or future prospects. Part of what makes cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology so potentially revolutionary lies in how they may be able to help that portion of humanity which currently lives in either under-developed or undeveloped areas of the planet. And this portion of humanity is extremely large indeed. To put things into perspective, a developed country (one with a status of "High Human Development") must have a Human Development Indexrating of 0.7 or greater. As of 2015 (the most recent year for which data is available) of the 188 countries listed on the registry only 105 meet this rating. To put it another way: only 55% of the world qualifies as having a high level of development. BLOCKCHAIN: THE GOOD Below are listed sevaral elements of daily life, the distributiona nd management of which could be greatly facilitated by blockchain technology. Estimates vary in terms of percentages and actual numbers but it is widely believed that currently 3.5 billion people or, roughly, half the worlds population currently live without them. They are:
  • passports:severe restrictions on travel and international mobility precluding access to opportunities for such things as education, employment or, in the worst cases escape from internal political strife
  • identification cards:severe obstacles in obtaining any type of documentation for 3rd party representation
  • deeds to their land and other property:the potential for utter disempowerment from above and/or severe complication in the event of the death of a family member or contestment of ownership
  • insurance policies: little to no fallback in the event of an accident or unforeseen calamity
  • drivers licenses:socio-economic disempowerment via an inability to legally transit any distance requiring an automobile
  • bank accounts: extremely limited 3rd party financial representation and severe limitations on any financial transactions nationally or internationlly not involving cash
  • credit history:little to no credibility for 3rd party services to refer to thus creating difficulties for loan approval or any accreditation preceding upward mobility.
  • formal education:socio-economic disadvantages in regard to social/business interactions as well as a kind of default igorance to "the ways of the world" in regard to how things are done.
  • language skills:severe limitations on opportunities for both making contact with and diseminating information necessary for betterment of current situation.
  • internet access: preclusion from the vast majority of global discourse concering current trends related to nearly every category of information known to humanity.
  • telephone services:an inability to communicate between disassociated geographical locations in real time and, thus, severe limitations on the sharing of relevant ideas and much needed discourse.
The average citizen of a developed country could likely go without one or two or maybe three of the elements listed above. But, to go without all would mean to live an exceptionally primitive life.Essentially, those who fall into this wopping segment of the worlds population are off the books, in the dark, unheard and, most importantly, strikingly disempowered. And it is this subtle notion of disempowerment which is largely responsible for a number of problems in the world. DISEMPOWERMENT? By disempowerment I am not speaking of an explicit effort to prevent access to something but more of an inadvertant type of exclusion. An exclusion brought about simply because the barrier to entry is far too high for those stuck in poverty. This does not simply impact the capacity to store or send one's money to and fro. No, it has far deeper and impending implications and that is because we are not simply speaking of money in and of itself. We are speaking moreso of how money can empower people to change their situation and improve their lives. What this inaccessibility really means is that some of the most mundane elements of modern life remain beyond access and many must face what must appear to them as an inescapable state of stagnation. The reasons for this largely revolve around: 1) a lack of infrastucture 2) a lack of funding and societal/political organization to facilitate construction and management of infrastructure in the first place It is a classic Catch 22 in that the solution to the problem requires the problem be solved (think of someone who has broken their glasses and need their glasses in order to fix their glasses). There is some assistance to be offered via financial investments from abroad via the World Bank or IMF. There is also benefit to be gained in the introduction of certain technologies like cellphones and wireless internet that supercede altogether the need for what are often the insurmountable amounts of capital necessary to create a more traditional infrastructure. Yet these efforts often tend to: Lack uniform application in their institution: large injections of capital rarely succeed in fulfilling the expectations of the fabled principle of "trickle down" wherein one lump sum given to a single institution somehow manages to benefit every single person in the surrounding area. This is especially true if the surrounding population does not possess the requesite level of education/qualificaiton to put them in direct touch with the movement of the capital. A typical example is one where a large, foreign based mining firm will pay significant sums to a local government for rights to mine an area but the capital itself will never reach the actual citizenry. It will instead, almost on impact as it were, be absorbed by the governmental institutions waiting in line for it long before ever actually changing the lives of the majority population. NOTE: Some promise has been shown regarding the practice of "micro-loaning" where in a comparatively small amount of money is loaned (or given)directlyto an individual and/or family "on the ground", so to speak, but this is largely an exception to the rule as currently practiced. Microloans, however do show a significant level of promise in how they can directly affect the quality of life the loanee and/or his/her family. A loan of only $100 USD, for example, may be enough for a marginalized family to send a family member to school for a year, build a house, pay for food, or even buy a plot of land. The implications of any and all of these changes are significant beyond measure for a population living below the poverty line. Fail to account for cultural/governmental customs and local "rule of law": culture is a huge factor. Not so much out of a sense of respect for diversity or a desire to preserve the intrinsic value of a given culture but more so because culture largely informshow a given population (within limits) either will or will not respond to a given situation.This point cannot be underestimated and, in taking the point further, it is more often the case that where one may attribute ignorance, aggression and/or stupidity to a given response from a party not of one's own background, the culprit is more often than not the result of a different cultural upbringing and not some perceived and projected fault in the individual or group themselves. As an example, the war in Iraq proved a total disaster almost exclusively because the United States failed to account for the cultural nuances of the different Muslim factions within the country and how that dynamic would evolve once the oppressive lid of the former administration was blown off by the American invasion and subsequent occupation. History is full of such stories and this is probably why both ancient Roman and Chinese culture requested only alliegance and some degree of literacy and linguistic ability (particularly from the elite) from their subjugates over a total conversion, as it were, to their way of doing things. The reason is that imposing one cultural imprint over another and expecting repeatable results has proven naive at best and disastrous at worst. So, with that said, it is rarely realistic to expect a blanket solution approach to bear fruit when it is being applied to a population with a cultural background not of one's own. This fact should be more obvious than it is but perhaps that is why the phrase "history repeats itself" is so very commonly right on the money. May serve to befuddle, derail, confuse or otherwise fail to have any positive effect on the general population:this point is very much in line with the notion mentioned immediately above of cultural interoparability being a pipe dream. However, it focuses more on the experience of the receiving end rather than as a phenomenon as such so merits separate mention. The receiving end being composed of individual human beings each with varying levels of awareness, capability, capacity and unpredictability it is necessary to focus on the dynamics here even if only in a general way. You see, it has been widely demonstrated that people rarely respond in a positve way to sudden and extreme change. As the old saying goes "give them too much rope and they'll hang themselves". This is not to blame any specific individual of incompetence but to point out the fact it is generally a good idea to have a means of transition in place when executing any large scale change. Evolution of any sort is generally accomodated by environmental changes over a period of time so it would stand to reason that providing the same type of situation in attempting to change the infrastucture or capacity of a population on an individual level. That is, in short, even the most well intentioned efforts of the people and institutions seeking to help the undeveloped world become more developed cannot escape the systemic inefficiencies and exclusive cost barriers of the current global way of doing things. None of this should be too surprising when we consider that we are effectively asking a population to pull themselves up by their bootstraps when they have no boots. To be clear, I personally don't see this as any fault of the system itself. And that is because the system itself is inefficient and incapable of not generating such predicaments. To blame the system itself for its failures would be the equivalent of blaming an inferior technology for failing to meet the performance standards of a superior one. It would be like blaming a horse for not being able to perform like a car. THE BAD? There are some that would argue that this type of technology may pose a catastrophic threat to financial and other data driven industries and even governments themselves. But I would argue differently. History has shown that, although the transition may be difficult, society and the industries that support it generally benefit from embracing new technological trends; although it may take some time for the trend to reach a level of recognition and acceptance signigicant enough for real change to happen. Of course, this type of change does require adaptation and sometimes to an extreme degree. It is likely that, in a world where cryptocurrency and blockchain are truly mainstream, there will be industries and services which we presently cant imagine. There could be, for example, specialist services for designing smart contracts to buy and sell a house as easily as you would order something off of Amazon. We could see online exchanges to download your paycheck onto your computer. And, of course, people in far flung areas of the planet with little or next to no infrastructure participating just as readily in the global exchange of commerce and creativity as anyone else in the first world. There is so much room for innovation when we turn our minds away from protectionism. CONCLUSION Although the promise of blockchain technology and the various cryptocurrencies/smart contracts that can and will move about on it is huge I feel I must temper my enthusiasm with a good helping of realism. There is no denying that, here in the Spring of 2018, the ratio of hype to real world application concerning this kind of technology leans more than a little bit toward the hype side. That is the world of speculation and trading on blockchain and crypto platforms far outweighs what they are bringing in terms of real, felt service to humanity. So it is no wonder that we hear insiders and big names from a wild variety of industries saying extreme and often contradictory things about it all. It seems the more intense and controversial a new innovation may be, the more intense and controversial will be its reception. So, while the John McAfees and Warren Buffets of the world may take opposite but equally strong stances, there is in the middle, beyond the hyperbole and posturing, something most definitely happening and it is substantial. To be fair, it is difficult to say how things will go from here and there may be some truth to the sentiment to that to speak at all in regard to crypto may be to speak to soon. We will see. Personally, while I don't believe that the blockchain is a magic cure-all bound to fix all of humanities problems I do believe it is a very smart step in the right direction. And I think a key factor in determing the success of blockchain technology will be the technology itself; especially when leveraged by the growing community of enthusiasts around the world seeking to make it happen.         [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology offer far more than just opportunity for market trading. The offer a chance to make more technology and transaction accessible to more people with fewer resources used.

item.title: STEEMIT: THE NEXT GENERATION OF CONTENT CREATION PLATFORMS?

Steemit is the first of its kind: a fusion of blockchain technology, crypto currency and human creativity. There has literally never been a platform like this. Continue reading to learn what Steemit is, how it works and why you should probably get involved.

item.title: WHAT IS A SMART CONTRACT?
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
[et_pb_section fb_built="1" _builder_version="3.0.47"][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.47" background_size="initial" background_position="top_left" background_repeat="repeat"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"]

 

A smart contract is a digital protocol which allows complex transactions to be executed in a highly automated way on a blockchain platform. While this definition is comparatively simple its implications are extremely far reaching and potentially revolutionary in terms of the types of services and transactions that could be leveraged.

Blockchain technology has, at its heart, the goal of removing a 3rd party from central control of the transaction process. Smart contracts add an additional layer of potential to this basic idea in offering an an incredible number of options for creating conditions, deadlines and contractual agreements to these blockchain transactions. This additional layer of blockchain based customization is where the real promise of smart contract technology lies.

But let us give a little more of a stage by stage approach to what smart contracts are and some background to their emergence on the blockchain/cryptocurrency scene. And, also, some reasons as to why they are becoming such a big deal and what makes them so potentially useful.

STAGE 1: YE OLDE BLOCKCHAIN

With the rise to public awareness of Bitcoin there has also come a growing focus on blockchain technology; the decentralized (in the best case) network on which the transactions are executed, stored and overseen. But of course blockchain technology is capable of handling far more than financial transactions alone. Such transactions are, after all, comparatively simple. The original work that led to the eventual formation of blockchain technology was focused on the exchange ofany digital media and not simply the sending back and forth of digital money. For all the fanfare and tech involved, the average financial transaction is about as complex as person A giving person B a certain amount of something and both parties being able to say that it happened. The "say that it happened" part has historically proven to be the most crucial element in commerce of any kind and is largely what makes the blockchain so innovative in the way it fulfills this objective.

LIMITATIONS OF FIRST GENERATION BLOCKCHAIN TRANSACTIONS

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89" custom_padding="2px|0px|1px|0px"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_image src="http://bitcoinbuildify.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/article-insert-I.jpg" _builder_version="3.0.89"][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"]

However, as ingenious as the simplicity and essentially foolproof nature of the blockchain may be, the essential nature of its transactions deal with sending to and fro packets of dataas such. That is, once a sender has decided on a destination and initiated a transaction for the given data, that data will be sent and received exactly as it is. No further conditions or obligations need apply for its successful completion to happen.

The essential role of a smart contract is to impose certain obligations and criteria on the transactionto be fulfilledbefore the transaction can be completed. A rough analogy would be that of an escrow service which holds funds until both parties are satisfied before they can be released thus completing the transaction. Only, because a smart contract is run on the blockchain, the service does not require a 3rd party and will execute its preset directives automatically. So it carries a higher level of security while requiring a lower expenditure of resources.

But let us return to the basics of what a constitute a transaction taking, as our example, the digital exchange of money. As it is with a simple financial transaction the only really pressing criteria to be fulfilled are:

  • verification of transmission of intended amount/data from the sender
  • verification of reception of intended amount/data by receiver

Typical records of a bitcoin transaction (blockchain browsers vary) will show just those elements. The withdrawal and deposit verification will typically consist of the sending and receiving wallet address alone and not who/where the end users are. This is part and parcel of the notion of privacy and independence underlying a good amount of the thinking in the blockchain/cryptocurrency world.

STAGE 2: IMPROVEMENTS ON THE TRANSACTIONABILITY OF BLOCKCHAIN REGISTERED EXCHANGES

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89" custom_padding="0px|0px|0px|0px"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_image src="http://bitcoinbuildify.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/article-insert-II.jpg" _builder_version="3.0.89"][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.89"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"]

The essential goal or genesis of blockchain technology was to allow any type digital media to be transacted (sent from Point A to Point B) in avery secure, decentralized and communally verified way. The mission was to create a transparent, secure "trustless network" to send "packets" of data without relying on a third party or in any way allowing corruptability or duplication of said packets. It was quite a tall order in its day and it wasn't until the publication of the Bitcoin Whitepaper that anyone could come up with a satisfactory way of doing it. And while the implementation and use of the Bitcoin blockchain has successfully established a precedent toward this end the actual dynamics of the transactions are remarkably simple; no more complex, really, for the end users than sending an email. That is, the sender sends the data and the receiver receives it exactly as it was sent. The only notable element here is that the transaction is verified and recorded on the blockchain by a decentralized community.

With a smart contract, however, there is another element added to the transaction: conditions to be met before the transaction can be completed. And these "conditions", as we will see later, can range from the very simple to the enormously complex.Essentially, smart contracts allowcontractual exchanges via blockchain technology and not just simply the sending and receiving of digital media. A contractual exchange means that there is an element of mediation and response occurring in real time to ensure the conditions of the agreement are met as stipulated in order for the contract to "execute" and thereby complete the transaction. Any failure on either end to meet the stipulated conditions of the contract will automatically change, suspend or even terminate the transaction.

It is a step up in complexity and so requires a different level of organization. This notion of "organization" in relation to the automated fulfillment of a contractual exchange is why such contracts are called "smart contracts"; they are essentially able to "decide" the outcome of a contractual agreement without any human intervention. They are able to monitor the fulfillment of obligations, protect data, initiate penalties/refunds/cancellations and so on based on preset conditionsautomatically.Smart contracts ensure that all parties involved in the transaction follow the rules

Further, all of this is taking place on the blockchainand the data is sent simultaneously to all parties involved in the contract. This may sound enormously complex (and for certain situations the conditions could very well be complex indeed) but the essential principles at play here are actually quite simple. The smart contract is essentially a software program tailored to the specific parameters of the transaction it is being used in. After the transaction is initiated, the smart contract "behaves" according to two criteria:

the conditions for execution have been met

the conditions for execution have not been met

There is of course some crossover among the elements listed above but, essentially, these are the protocols which guide a smart contract's "behavior". If the conditions for execution have been met, the smart contract will automatically execute. If the conditions for execution have not been met, the smart contract will pursue another option such as suspending or terminating the transaction.

Let's give a more concrete example:

Situation: you decide to rent a beach house for 5 days while you are on vacation. The beach house is in a foreign country some 7,000 miles from where you live. You have never been there before and you do not speak the language. You go online and use the rental company's smart contract option to secure your stay. You stipulate when you will arrive and when you will leave. You then pay the deposit and confirm the transaction. All of this is recorded on the blockchain.

The smart contract is initiated and begins to count down to preset deadlines based on the parameters of your reservation. We'll call these specific parameters directives.

Directive 1: email client access code to beach house lock 24 hours before arrival

Directive 2: render code useable 20 minutes before client's scheduled time of arrival

Directive 3: inform rental company of client's arrival when the door to the beach house is opened

Directive 4: render access code unuseable 2 hours after client's scheduled checkout time

And so on and so forth. For each of the directives above, sub-directives could be programmed in should any of the conditionsnot be met. If, for example the door was not opened with the given access code within a specified period after the client's scheduled time of arrival an automatic email could be sent to the rental company informing them of the situation. Or, if the client never showed up there could be a directive to either refund or keep the deposit.

WHAT MAKES SMART CONTRACTS UNIQUE?

One could definitely argue that a good amount of the complex transactions smart contracts are designed to facilitate could be handled via other means. There is no shortage of platforms and services out there each with their associated specialists, fees, and tactics. But, unless they are employing distributed blockchain technology, they remain extremely susceptible to all of the security problems associated with 3rd party monopolies over end user transactions. With smart contracts, everything happens on the blockchain and so the enforcment of the contract at the time and its subsequent record are absolutely air tight. The immutable nature of smart contract transactions could mean an unprecedented reduction in fraud and theft via digital transaction across the world.This, again, would equate to savings in terms of time, resources and funding that are not to be underestimated.

Further, once initiated, the majority of enforcement of the contract will happen automatically according to the protocols programmed into the agreement. This includes enforcement and oversight of both the obligations of the contract and the penalties for failing to meet them. Although there could be special types of directives allowing a more human touch to certain unforeseen contingencies or changes. But even this would require the smart contract to take some kind of action like suspending the transaction and alerting all parties involved to the need for further action to be taken.

There is essentially no limit to the kinds of transactions that could be mediated by smart contracts and the potential range of their real world applications is absolutely enormous. Literally any type of dealing with the need for digital representation could benefit from a smart contract. And, often, the more complex the deal or contractual bond the more a smart contract can streamline the transaction. Further, like the substratum of blockchain technology they run on, smart contracts' high level of automated enforcement and real-time responsiveness could prove to be an enormously efficient way of saving resources in the form of time, labor and cost for a whole plethora of different types of complex, delicate and often expensive transactions.They would also virtually eliminate the occurence of human error and negligence which can often be enormously expensive in and of themselves.

Further, there are even developments concerning the intereactions of smart contracts withothersmart contracts to create a completely automated organization known as "decentralized autonomous organization".

So let's break down the essential points of what make smart contracts a good idea and potentially a world changing option in the realm of digital transactions. Smart contracts:

  • facilitate extremely complex transactions with multiple phases of execution and conditions to be met before finalization
  • leverage the resource and cost saving technology of blockchain to a phenomenal degree
  • allow direct, peer-to-peer exchanges of a potentially unlimited variety of digital documents with contractual rights and obligations concerning the exchange in full effect
  • can be tailored and customized to a very high degree making their range of potential application essentially unlimited
  • carry out directives automatically and leave a blockchain encoded record of their transactions that is tamperproof

THINGS TO COME

With the continuing evolution of smart contract technology the likelihood of mass adoption of blockchain technology becomes ever more possible. Especially when we consider the level of flexibility and customization smart contract applications would allow. There are parellels here, too, between the evolution of the computer and its gradual but inevitable proliferation first in business and then in our social lives as well. And the potential for leverage and change to our individual capacity and daily lives brought about by the PC could likely be rivalled if not surpassed by the promise of smart contract technology.

Smart contracts are essentially introducing a way to "bridge the gap" between what may at one time have been a very limited niche of individuals and organizations with a need for blockchain technology and the greater public. Just as the internet was originally incepted as a means for "nerds to talk between universities" and then grew to become a true revolution in communication and commerce, smart contracts may likely come to infuse our daily lives in ways both subtle and great.

But only time (and our collective efforts) will tell.

Once you send us an email, a real human will get in touch with you within 48 hours at the most. None of the information you share with us will be made available to any 3rd parties without first getting your interest and permission to do so. We hate spam just as much as you do.

item.title: ICENTER.CO: SCAM OR NO SCAM? MY BEST AT A FAIR REVIEW
item.dc:creator: Trevor272
item.content:encoded:
[et_pb_section fb_built="1" _builder_version="3.0.47"][et_pb_row _builder_version="3.0.47" background_size="initial" background_position="top_left" background_repeat="repeat"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="3.0.89" parallax="off" parallax_method="on"][et_pb_text _builder_version="3.0.89"]

SCAMS AND WHATNOT

Before I get into my experiences with icenter.co and the details of my, experience with them and whether I think they're a scam or not, let me say a few words about scams in the cryptocurrency industry.

There is no doubt that scams in the cryptocurrency arena do exist. And some of them are outwardly very convincing. Let's face it, scammers have only gotten better not worse with the passage of time. But why does the cryptocurrency arena seem so prone to scams? Consider the following points:

Consumer ignorance: this applies equally well to both cryptocurrencies and the more widely adaptable technology of blockchain. Few have the requisite coding and software knowledge it would really take to tell a legit project from one that is not. They may also be lacking in a sound understanding of finance in general and what money actually is. Further, the principle of tokenization of services (a large part of the reason for the bewildering number of different ICOs out there) is almost unlimited meaning that you would need a huge amount of knowledge in not only the ICO itself but the market it is targeting.

Lack of regulation: things are changing here in 2018 but, until very, very recently, there has been little to no regulation regarding the launching of ICOs, trading with crypto, or advertising crypto/blockchain related services. This has allowed the good to rise in tandem with bad and is largely responsible for why the reputation of the movement has not always been the best.

Online anonymity: for the average consumer, the internet offers a level of anonymity for service providers that would have been unprecedented in earlier times. There is also the fact that the internet has a global reach. So, the unwitting can very easily find themselves trusting a party they know nothing about as in who they are, where they are and what the company they represent is really about.

There is some truth to the hype: finally we have the fact that, although rare, there are people out there who have made amazing financial gains in cryptocurrencies. Their numbers may be relatively few but there are enough success stories out there to encourage those with even a little bit of curiousity to try it out for themselves.

 

So, considering the points listed above, we can see that there is the perfect confluence of elements for the less reputable to prey upon the less informed in cryptocurrencies.

IT'S JUST BEGINNING

crypto is really still in its infancy. This means the potential for innovation and development in this field is also in its infancy. And there are few fields in the world today with as much potential for development and application as blockchain and cryptocurrency technology. So it is definitely true that there will be those ICOs and blockchain platforms, many of which may not even have been invented yet, that will see unbelievable returns on investment. There will be the crypto/blockchain equivalents of Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple in the years to come. And, as many of us have with these very same giants today, we may look back in 10 or 20 years on the beginnings of the crypto/blockchain giants of the future only to lament not having bought in earler.

The problem is it would take an almost impossibly rare combination of luck and penetrating insight into the market to know what to go with here in 2018 in order to realize these mythical gains in another decade or so. Therein lies the rub. But the enticement of it, the chance of it actually happening to you are part of what makes it so exciting and so easy to be scammed.

So, with utter scams on one side and true stories of huge success on the other it seems the key is to find the middle ground and stick to it. The best way to do this is to do your research on the platforms and coins you are working with. And there is an ubelievable variance among the different projects out there. Some of them are amazing, some of them are crap and almost none of them has seen anything more than a shadow of use in the real world. For the time being, most of the action in cryptocurrencies is happening either on the drawing board or in the realm of market speculation. And this is exactly why the market is so volatile; it is being driven not by real world demand but by the chasing to and fro of ideas and buying trends.The market is fickle as can be and, scam or no scam, there is no place in the world where it is easier to lose all of your money.

And now, to the main subject: is icenter.co a scam?

The answer: I don't know.

My experience with them has been exactly as advertised; better sometimes even because they often up their return percentages to celebrate landmarks in their numbers or anniversaries and whatnot. I have never had an issue with depositing, withdrawing or accumulating the promised returns while invested. But this does not, of course, mean they are or are not a scam. They could be a ponzi/pyramid scheme in which funds are generated via deposits from new sign ups but neither myself nor anyone I know would be able to verify this without access to the backend of the company. I am certain, however, that they are certainly not a scam in the sense of stealing your funds outright and disappearing never to be heard from again. They are not a scam in the sense of posting fake data in your account. And they are not a scam of saying one thing and doing another.

I personally don't understand the outright insistence that this company is a scam. But I must keep in mind that this is crypto. Scams exist and they are ruthless. So while it may be out of line to accuse a company outright of being a scam just because you feel like saying so in most industries, in crypto it is nearly always a valid question. And, if you are even considering buying in, it is a question you would do well to find an answer to beyond a shadow of a doubt.

So let me divide the next section of this post into two focus areas: 1) Why icenter.co might be a scam and 2) why icenter.co might not be a scam. I think this is the fairest, most objective approach to the issue. And please keep in mind that while I do hold a position with icenter.co, I am neither encouraging nor discouraging you sign with them. I really just want to provide some legit, non-salesy data on how they work, what my experience with them has been and why they may or may not be a scam.

I will try to keep things as objective and "middle of the road" as possible.

WHY ICENTER.CO MIGHT BE A SCAM

The owners of the company are reluctant to reveal who they are: this may be the mark of a scam or it may be that the owners, whoever they are, simply don't want the attention of certain parties. Personally, I don't agree with being vague about who you are in what are perfectly legal business dealings but they may indeed have their reasons. There are powerful people in high places who do not like crypto and offering a platform to the masses encouraging its proliferation may not be very well received.

The company is, in general, extremely vague about their operations: this, again, may mean they are simply scamming their clientele blind. It could also mean that they wish to keep the particulars of their operation in the dark simply as an industrial secret. Software being as copiable as it is, they would have every right to do so. Although other industries may suffer less skepticism they are equally as quiet about their own proprietary software and applications as icenter.co is about theirs.

The promised returns seem unusually high/diffiult to guarantee: SCAM!!! Or it could be that with the increasing proliferation of automation in the trading world in general icenter.co is simply providing to their clientele what the good old boys in the banking world have been giving themselves.

There is a lot of buzz on the internet saying they are a scam: obviously, given the elements above, icenter.co could do better in the way of making themselves reputable in the industry. Not doing so simply leaves them open as a target for slander and a means for marketers of questionable character to defame icenter.co's name in order to promote their own offer. This is an unfortunately common tactic with little or no recourse.

WHY ICENTER.CO MIGHT NOT BE A SCAM

People working with them are seeing results: personally I have had no trouble depositing, viewing, growing and withdrawing BTC in icenter.co. So far they have been doing what they advertise and I have no complaints save for how confusing it can be to figure out how to make a withdrawal.

They haven't collapsed or been shut down: This may seem kind of a strange thing to say but regulators have proven to be quite aggressive toward other crypto operations resembling icenter.co. I personally went through quite a bit of drama with another, similar platform. The fact that icenter.co, ponzi scheme or not, is still going is something worth noting.

They are continuing to grow: this would indicate their current clientele are satisfied enough with their experience to recruit other signups. It is important to note, also, that promotion isnot required with icenter.co. You can simply deposit however much BTC you're comfortable with, run it through its 120 cycle and say goodbye. No questions asked, no pressure. With the typical ponzi scheme, new enrollees are often required to recruit other signups and "build their downline" in order to keep a fresh stream of income to trickle up the ladder.

This is not the case with icenter.co

FINAL THOUGHTS

Despite my personal experience investing with this company, I can neither confirm nor deny they are a scam. I have seen results and they have been consistent. However, there is no real way for me to confirm where these results are coming from. The company does itself no favor by remain so aloof about who they are and I would have difficulty explaining why the do this.

Also, I have only been involved with them for about 3 months. The standard contract length is 120 days. I have been able to both deposit and withdraw without any problems but I did find the withdrawal process a little less than clear. This was slightly concerning. It's not that you can't make a withdrawal. It's simply that it's not immediately clear how to do so. This was the first platform I've worked with that had this issue.

On the bright side, the company passed their one year mark as of June 7th 2018. This tells me either A) they are doing well enough with their legit operations to keep their customers happy or B) their ponzi scheme is still in its early phases and they are receiving enough signups to keep it going. Again, I have no way to know for sure. But nor do I have any way to guarantee thatany ICO or any investment platformisn't a scam.

My advice to you is, if you're interested in giving icenter.co a go, do so at your own risk and decide for yourself based on your results. I don't say this because I believe they are a scam. I say this because it has proven exceedingly difficult to prove they are not a scam. I have personally been scammed before (not in crypto) and can tell you it's not a pleasant experience.

Well, that about does it for my rundown on icenter.co. I hope you found this review helpful. If you have any questions, don't be shy about asking.

We have a little more of an old school approach to servicing our clients:

 

  • no automated emails,

  • no hiding who we are

 

We believe in quality over quantity and want our customers to have a full understanding and appreciation of what theyre getting into. This helps us just as much as it helps you.

 

Once you send us an email, a real human will get in touch with you within 48 hours at the most. None of the information you share with us will be made available to any 3rd parties without first getting your interest and permission to do so. We hate spam just as much as you do.

The world of crypto does have its scams. Is icenter.co one of them? Well, it's hard to say.The best I can do is to share my experience with you.
